loans.name: Sophal

texts.en:
Mr. Sophal H. (pictured above) and his wife, Mrs. Savun Yoeun, have been married since 1995. They live on an island in the Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh. 

Sophal builds wooden houses. His wife sells groceries at home and raises pigs. He is asking for a loan of 300 USD to purchase more piglets for his wife to raise.

loans.use: to purchase additional piglets for his wife to raise

loans.name: Iron

texts.en:
Iron, a 28-year-old man is running a broiler business. He is married to Magdalena, 26 years old, who is working at a store. Iron has a daughter, namely: Risa, 4 years old who is in PAUD (Play group). Actually, Iron is working as a teacher in PAUD. Since the salary generated is too small, he has to run a business to support his family.

 Prior to running the business, Iron learnt how to raise and to look after chicks from his relatives.  Iron started his business with his own capital and it is running well. Now he plans to expand his business by buying six boxes of chicks to be raised. He is requesting a loan of 7,500,000 from TLM. He is expecting that TLM will be willing to assist him in expanding his business.

loans.use: To purchase six boxes of chicks to be raised

loans.name: Wilma

texts.en:
Wilma R. is from the town of Rizal, Quirino, Isabela. She is 47 years old. Wilma is married and has two adult children. To make a living, Wilma owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Wilma has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 6000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Wilma joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Wilma has successfully repaid a previous loan of 25,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. Wilma is requesting a new loan of 25,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise. This will be the 7th loan taken out by Wilma from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise

loans.name: Chandalis

texts.en:
Mrs. Chandalis T. (pictured with her loom) is 26 years old, and her husband, Mr. Longvanna Ven, is 28 years old. They live on an Island in the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh City. They have been married since 2008 and have one son and one daughter. All of them are still young. 

Chandalis is a weaver. Her husband is a security guard. She is applying for a loan of $700 to purchase weaving materials for her weaving business.

loans.use: to purchase weaving materials for her weaving business.

loans.name: Sanobar's Group

texts.en:
Sanobar lives in Jaranwala which is located in Punjab province, Pakistan and known for its agriculture industry. Her house contains 3 rooms and made of bricks. She has been living there for past two years with her family. She is 35 years old, a very active lady, and spends her time at home doing her household responsibilities.

Her husband’s name is W. A. and he is 36 years old. He operates a LPG (liquid petroleum gas) cylinder sales business. His clientele is made up of rickshaw drivers. Gas is a high demand product and W. earns a good profit every month with his business. 

Sanobar is the mother of three children; two of them are enrolled in a local school and getting their education. The youngest one is only a year old. Sanobar knows the importance of education and wants her children to become successful in their lives by getting good quality education. 

She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband who wants to improve his business.  Through the loan, he will buy more gas cylinders to sell which will help him earn better profits. Sanobar is hopeful that an investment will be profitable for him. She is a new loan user and this is her 1st loan application to Asasah. She hopes that it will be gainful experience for her family.

loans.use: To buy LPG gas cylinders for resale.

loans.name: Tserendulam

texts.en:
Tserendulam is 38 years old and a widow who lives with her three children in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. They all live in a small wooden house on her brother’s plot of land. She has been operating a tailoring business for the last 5 years and now she has six sewing machines, employs two tailors, and sells her products to companies or persons by contract. Her older two sons are attending a local secondary school and the youngest son goes to kindergarten. 

Tserendulam is an open person who has very good communication skills and is providing a good education for her children all by herself. She  is grateful to those responsible for making her dream come true, so she promises to complete her  payments by the established deadlines. She is requesting a 1.500.000 MNT loan to increase her working capital by purchasing another sewing machine and a steam iron from Ereen, the border city of China, because it is cheaper than to buy them in Mongolia.

loans.use: to purchase another sewing machine and a steam iron

loans.name: Savoeun

texts.en:
Mrs. Savoeun R. and her husband, Mr. Vuthy Soy, live in a village across the Mekong River, approximately twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh City. They have three children, two attend school and another one is still young. 

Savoeun is a weaver. Her husband is a security guard. In the past, he was a construction worker. Savoeun asked for a Kiva loan once. She hopes to continue her weaving business, so she is asking for her second loan of $600 to purchase weaving materials (cotton threads). She will also use a part of the loan to repair the roof of her house.  

Photo: Mrs. Savoeun R. and her loom

loans.use: to purchase weaving materials and to repair the roof of her house

loans.name: 35. Thi Tran.thieu Hoa Group

texts.en:
Yen N. T. (7) is a 36-year-old woman living in the town of T. T. Thieu Hoa Thanh Hoa.  Yen is the group leader of a 3-member group loan offered by Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.  The official name of this borrowing group is 35. T. T.. Thieu hoa (12.03.35).


Yen is married and has one infant child.  To make a living, Yen operates a family member's business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock.  While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from raising cattle for sale.  Yen has been engaged in this business for over 15 years and earns approximately 2,000,000 VND a month from these activities.


In 2011, Yen joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  Yen is requesting a loan from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women in the amount of 5,787,900 VND which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in future.  The will be the 12th loan taken out by the borrower from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  Yen plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.


About the Other Borrowers in the Group:


1.  T. T. van (8) is a 49-year-old woman who is requesting a 5,787,900 VND loan to support her business raising livestock.


2.  T. T. nhan (9) is a 31-year-old woman who is requesting a 5,787,900 VND loan to support her business  raising livestock.


About Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

The mission of Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women (FPW) is to provide sustainable financial services to disadvantaged women in rural areas in the Thanh Hoa province.


*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.


yen N. T. (7) là 36 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy sống ở thành phố T. T. Thieu Hoa Thanh Hoa.  yen là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 3 các thành viên.  Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ..  Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là 35. T. T.. Thieu hoa (12.03.35).


Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ chăn nuôi gia súc để bán.  yen thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 15 năm.  Từ các hoạt động này, yen kiếm được khoảng 2,000,000 VND.  Vào 2011, yen đã tham gia Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải T.ện  sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy.  yen đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.    Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 5,787,900 VND.


Khoản vay sẽ là 12th khoản vay của người vay từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.


Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm:


1.  T. T. van (8) là 49 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5,787,900 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.


2.  T. T. nhan (9) là 31 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5,787,900 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.


Về Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

Nhiệm vụ của Quỹ vì Phụ Nữ Nghèo Thanh Hóa (FPW) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính bền vững cho những người phụ nữ kém may mắn ở các vùng nông thôn tỉnh Thanh Hóa.


*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. .  Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng  Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.  .

loans.use: to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in future.

To make a living, Geraldine owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Geraldine has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Geraldine joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Geraldine has successfully repaid a previous loan of 22,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. Geraldine is requesting a new loan of 21,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise. This will be the 7th loan taken out by Geraldine from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

loans.name: Florentina

texts.en:
Florentina Z. is from the village of Upper Solana, Jasaan, Misamis Oriental. She is 52 years old. Florentina is married and has four adult children. To make a living, Florentina owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling daily use products such as canned goods, snack foods, detergents & beverages in the local community. Florentina has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Florentina joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Florentina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Florentina is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell like canned goods & snack foods. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by Florentina from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell like canned goods & snack foods.

loans.name: Sim

texts.en:
Mrs. Sim D. (pictured with her grandson) and her husband, Mr. Sokhom Mao, live in suburb of Phnom Penh approximately 25 kilometers away. They have been married since 1985 and have two daughters. One is married and is a garment factory worker, and the other one is in university.  

Sim stays at home and does housework. Her husband is a soldier. The main sources of income are her husband's and daughter’s salaries. She is asking for her first loan of $500 to purchase a computer laptop for her daughter who is in university.

loans.use: to purchase a computer laptop for her daughter

loans.name: Egil

texts.en:
Egil P. is from the village of Upper Solana, Jasaan, Misamis Oriental. She is 19 years old. Egil is married. To make a living, Egil owns & operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling coconuts & green bananas in the local community. Egil has been engaged in her business for over one year and earns approximately 7000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2011, Egil joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Egil is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional bananas & coconuts. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Egil from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.name: Sophea

texts.en:
Mrs. Sophea S. (in the photo with her loom) and her husband, Mr. Proeung Un, live on an island in the Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh. They have been married since 1989 and have one son and two daughters. One has full-time employment in Phnom Penh, one assists her mother in the business and another one attends school. 

Sophea is a silk weaver. Her husband is a farmer. Sophea asked for a Kiva loan once. She hopes to continue her weaving business, so she is asking for another loan of $200 to purchase weaving materials.

loans.use: to purchase weaving materials for her weaving business

Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ chăn nuôi gia súc để bán.  Sinh thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 30 năm.  Từ các hoạt động này, Sinh kiếm được khoảng 2,000,000 VND.  Vào 2011, Sinh đã tham gia Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải thiện  sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy.  Sinh đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.    Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 5,787,900 VND.


Khoản vay sẽ là 1st khoản vay của người vay từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.


Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm:


1.  Lê Thị Thu (14) là 53 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5,787,900 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.


2.  N. T. Sơn (13) là 30 tuổi nam.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5,787,900 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.


Về Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

Nhiệm vụ của Quỹ vì Phụ Nữ Nghèo Thanh Hóa (FPW) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính bền vững cho những người phụ nữ kém may mắn ở các vùng nông thôn tỉnh Thanh Hóa.


*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. .  Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (T. Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng  Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.  ."

loans.use: to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in future

loans.name: Remedios

texts.en:
Remedios P. is from the town of Rizal, Quirino, Isabela. She is 51 years old, married and has five adult-aged children. To make a living, Remedios owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector planting and harvesting rice for sale. Remedios has been engaged in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP per month from these activities.
In 2007, Remedios joined Kiva partner, ASKI, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 23,000 PHP from ASKI. This loan was used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. Remedios is requesting a new loan of 26,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise. This loan will be her seventh from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

About ASKI
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise

loans.name: Madeline

texts.en:
Madeline G. is from the village of Upper Solana, Jasaan, Misamis Oriental. She is 35 years old, married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Madeline owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, canned goods, junk foods and detergents in the local community. Madeline has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP per month from these activities.
In 2007, Madeline joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Madeline is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional canned goods, junk foods and detergents. This loan will be her second from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

About HSPFI
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional canned goods, junk foods and detergents

loans.name: Phalla

texts.en:
Mrs. Phalla S. (in the photo) is 38 years old and her husband, Mr. Vuthy Nao is 36 years old. They live on an island in the Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh. They have been married since 1997 and have two young daughters. 

Phalla and her husband are silk weavers. They sell their finished products to a middleman who then takes them to sell at the Phnom Penh market. Phalla is asking for her first loan of $1,200 to purchase a motorbike for her brother to get to work.

loans.use: to purchase a motorbike for her brother to get to work

loans.name: Seam

texts.en:
Mrs. Seam A. (in the photo) lives in a village across the Mekong River, approximately twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh City. She has four children - two sons and two daughters. One has full-time employment, one is a construction worker, one is weaver and another one is in school. 

Seam sells mangoes. She buys them under contract from her fellow villagers and transports them to sell in the Phnom Penh market. Her husband assists her in the business. Seam is asking for her first loan of $1,000 to purchase additional mangoes for resale.

loans.use: to purchase mangoes under contract for resale

loans.name: Saturnina

texts.en:
Saturnina M. is from the town of Rizal, Quirino, Isabela. She is 59 years old, married and has five adult-aged children. To make a living, Saturnina owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector planting and harvesting rice for sale. Saturnina has been engaged in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP per month from these activities.
In 2007, Saturnina joined Kiva partner, ASKI, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI. This loan was used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. Saturnina is requesting a new loan of 21,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise. This loan will be her seventh from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

About ASKI
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise

loans.name: Va

texts.en: Va S. is married and resides with her husband in Takeo province, Cambodia, an area known for its pre-Angkorean temples. S. sells coffee, earning an income of $5 USD per day. Her husband is a motor-taxi driver, earning an income of $5 USD per day. Each month, the family has to spend  $42 USD on food and $15 USD on other necessary expenses. S. is requesting a loan of $500 USD to purchase more coffee to resell. In the future, she would like to use the additional income generated from her business to repair her house. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: to buy more coffee for resale

loans.name: Zahida's Group

texts.en:
Zahida belongs to Jaranwala which is a small city of Punjab, Pakistan, known for its agriculture industry. She has been living there in a 2-room brick house with her family for the past 14 years. She is a caring lady and carries out her responsibilities of a housewife very well. She has given birth to five children. All of them are enrolled in a local school and getting their education. 

Her husband’s name is A. R. and he runs a garment shop in the market where he sells children's and ladies' garments to his customers. He is very good in customer relations and treats his customers with great respect. That’s why he has built up a good customer base, people buy garments from him regularly. 

Zahida has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband’s garment businesses. Through the loan, he will buy more garments for his shop which will allow him to earn more profits by increasing his sales. He has been operating this business for the past five years and Zahida is very confident about its growth in result of investment. 

She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her 4th loan application. She is a responsible client and has maintained a good credit record in every loan year. 

Note: In the photo, the lady with a book (called Asasah Passbook) is Zahida.

loans.use: To buy garments for resale.

loans.name: Dom

texts.en:
Mr. Dom D. is 32 years old, and his wife, Mrs. Chanda Yon, is also 32 years old (pictured together). They live in a village across the Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh. They have been married since 2000 and have two sons. One is in school and another one is still young. 

Dom is a chef. He cooks for a restaurant in Phnom Penh. His wife is a tailor. In addition, the couple also grows lotus. They hire their fellow villagers to grow lotus. Dom is asking for his first loan of $1,000 to purchase seed, fertilizer and pesticide to maintain his lotus farm and to pay for planting fees.

loans.use: To purchase seed, fertilizer and pesticide to maintain his lotus farm and to pay for planting fees.

loans.name: Chhun

texts.en:
Chhun C. is married and resides with her husband in Takeo province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-Angkorean temples. C. sells vegetables, earning an income of USD 6 per day. Her husband is a construction foreman, earning an income of USD 8 per day. Each month, the family has to spend USD 42 on food and USD 35 on the other necessary expenses. 

C. is requesting a loan of USD 1200 to purchase more supplies to expand her husband’s construction business. In the future, she would like to use the additional income to repair her house. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a long standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: buy more construction supplies to expand her husband's business

loans.name: Toch

texts.en:
Toch C. is married and resides with her husband in Takeo province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-Angkorean temples. C. is a farmer, earning an income of USD 2 per day. Her husband is a blacksmith, earning an income of USD 2 per day. Each month, the family has to spend USD 42 on food and USD 20 on other necessary expenses. 

C. is requesting a loan of USD 250 to purchase equipment to produce rice wine. In the future, she would like to use the additional income to repair her house. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a long standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: to buy equipment to produce rice wine

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to dig a fish pond to raise fish

loans.name: Safia's Group

texts.en:
Safia lives in Jaranwala which is a small city of Punjab, Pakistan and known for its agriculture industry. She has been living there with her family in a 2-room brick house for almost 16 years. 

Her husband’s name is S. P. and he is a painter by trade. He paint houses, walls and buildings on order. He makes contracts with different companies and also works for individuals on a daily wage. He has good skills in his work and receives regular orders every month. 

Safia is a housewife who prefers to stay at home and perform her household responsibilities. She is a very caring mother and takes care of her children very well. She has two sons and a daughter. Her eldest son operates a grocery shop while her remaining children are studying at a local school. She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah to improve her husband’s business. With the loan, her husband will buy paint and brushes that will help him offer better quality services to his clients and earn better profits. 

He has been doing this work for the past 10 years and Safia is confident that the loan investment will help him earn more profits from his work. Safia is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her 3rd loan application. In previous loan years, she has always paid her installments on time and never missed a single meeting.

loans.use: To buy paint and brushes for her husband's painting service.

loans.name: Lay

texts.en:
Lay K. is a 57-year-old widowed villager who lives in the Kompong Cham province. She is the mother of two children, one of whom is married and the other one is single. Her husband died of senility years ago. 

She is a local farmer who has been planting a variety of crops for years. She also relies on income from her daughter, who is a sewing worker. 

Lay K. has planned to open a small grocery kiosk near her house for selling a few items, but she doesn’t have enough money to do that. To achieve her goal, she would like to ask for a loan from Kiva’s partner HKL in order to purchase some essential goods for running her grocery business. This will allow her to increase her income to ensure that her entire family can attain a good standard of living.

loans.use: to purchase some essential goods for running her grocery business.

loans.name: Oyun

texts.en: Oyun, 51, is widowed and lives with her daughter in Uvs province of Mongolia. They live in a ger, Mongolian nomadic housing tent, on a small plot of land that they have owned since 1997. Her daughter attends a college. Oyun began growing and selling vegetables in 1996. In the beginning she used to grow only a few kinds of vegetables, but increased the variety of her vegetables in 2005. She grows tomatoes, carrots and beets in the spring and collects about 10 to 15 tons of crops in the fall. Now she rents a stall at a food market where she sells vegetables. She has a storage building nearby her house. She stores about 15 tons of vegetables in the building and sells them throughout the winter. Her current working capital exceeds 4,650,000 MNT. She is planning to buy more land where she can grow more vegetables and she wants to enlarge her storage unit. She is a hardworking and sociable person who says, " I am trying to increase my profit and save more money in order to pay my daughter's tuition fees."  She is requesting a loan of 3,000,000 MNT to purchase more vegetables for her business.

loans.use: to purchase more vegetables

loans.name: Nazia's Group

texts.en:
Nazia is a resident of Jaranwala which is a small city located in Punjab province and known for its agriculture, particularly rice crops. Her house has 2 rooms and she has been living in it with her family for the past 7 years. Her husband’s name is M. I. and he makes truck bodies. He is very talented in his work and also creates beautiful art work on truck bodies by using different colors on them. Nazia has given birth to 3 sons. All of them are very young and have not started going school yet. Nazia wants her children to get a quality education to become successful persons in their lives. She wants to improve her husband’s business so that she may send her eldest son, who is now 5 years old, to school. 

Nazia has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for the improvement of her husband’s business. He will buy iron in bulk quantity for making truck bodies. This will help him to complete the orders in less time and earn extra profits. Nazia has a firm believe that money attracts money and she is hopeful that her husband’s business will grow in a positive direction after making the loan investment into it. She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her fourth loan application. In previous loan years, she has maintained a good credit behavior and never missed any meeting. 

Note: In the photo, the lady with a book (called Asasah Passbook) is Nazia.

loans.use: to buy iron for making truck bodies

loans.name: Try

texts.en:
From Phnom Penh City of Cambodia, sewing clothes is the key part of 31-year-old Try S.’s daily routine. She provides her service to her neighbors, sewing both traditional clothes and modern clothes. She runs her business very well, and a lot of customers recognize the good service she provides. 

She is married to Meng Vuthy, 33, a chief of construction workers, and they have two children. Two of their daughters are studying in the local school.

Try S. will use half of her loan to mend her old house, and the rest of the money to buy more tailoring tools for her sewing business.

loans.use: To mend her old house and to buy more tailoring tools for her sewing business.

loans.name: Sadites

texts.en:
Sadites E. is from the village of Upper Solana, Jasaan, Misamis Oriental. She is 46 years old. Sadites is single. To make a living, Sadites owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, snack foods, canned goods, instant noodles and breads in the local community. Sadites has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Sadites joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Sadites has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and increase working capital. Sadites is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell like canned goods and snack foods. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Sadites from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell, like canned goods and snack foods

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
At 50, Teresita D. still has to make an effort to achieve a sense of accomplishment. She presently resides in Caloocan City where she stays with her two children and runs her own micro business. Teresita is widow who works very hard to earn a living and to be able to send all of her children to college.

Teresita is already working to a point where other dreams lie. She already has her own grocery, which is a dream to many sari-sari (variety) store owners. She has spent 11 years to establish the grocery in her community.  She offers basic commodities like groceries, rice, beverages, generic drugs, school supplies, accessories, and electronic loading for cell phone credits on all local networks. Every month, she earns an estimated net income of around PHP 12,400.

To help her continue operation of her business, Teresita is requesting for a PHP 50,000 loan.  With this money, she will secure the supplies for her grocery store, including food items, rice, school supplies, and electronic loading for mobile phones.

Vacations become quite a hindrance to Teresita, as less customers go to her grocery to purchase school snacks for their children. Still, it is her goal that every time her customers buy they will find all they need in her store. Teresita desires to help those who are needy because for her, happiness and contentment can be achieved with a sense of accomplishment by helping others.

As a CCT community partner, she faithfully attends the group's weekly fellowship* meeting. She can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she receives from these meetings.

*All CCT community partners and clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To replenish grocery supplies.

loans.name: Irene

texts.en:
Irene T. is from the village of Talusan, Balingasag, Misamis Oriental. She is 29 years old. Irene is single and has 1 adult child. To make a living, Irene owns & operates a specialized retail store, selling a variety of vegetables like squash, stringbeans & eggplants in the local community. Irene has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 6000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2011, Irene joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Irene is requesting a new loan of 4000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional vegetables to sell like potatoes & carrots. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Irene from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional vegetables to sell, like potatoes & carrots.

loans.name: Genie

texts.en:
Encouragement is like energy to a tired soul, and Genie T. proves so. Genie, 58, is married to Roel and is currently running her own sari-sari (variety) store. They have four children who all stay at home in Ascoville, Malaria, Caloocan City.

Genie’s sari-sari store is located very near their home, so she can manage it simultaneously with her household chores. The store has been running for five years now. As she meets the immediate needs of her neighbors for instant food and toiletries, Genie is able to earn PHP4,800 as a net income monthly.

To help her continue operations of her business, she would like to request for a PHP20,000 loan. She will use this money to purchase additional merchandise for her store, such as sachets of shampoo, coffee, and canned goods. Genie sees this loan as an encouragement for her to strive all the more for the improvement of her store. Indeed, the store allows her to increase the level of her lifestyle.

Vacations are a hindrance to the daily sales of her store. But she is currently working on her strategies to cope with such time of the year. Genie desires to see her store gradually turn into a grocery.

As a CCT community partner, she faithfully attends the group's weekly fellowship* meetings where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she receives.

*All CCT community partners and clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise.

loans.name: Ferdinand

texts.en:
Ferdinand P. is from the town of Rizal, Quirino, Isabela. He is 38 years old. Ferdinand is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Ferdinand raises crops, primarily rice, for sale. Ferdinand has been engaged in his business for over 19 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2011, Ferdinand joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. Ferdinand has successfully repaid a previous loan of 25,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. Ferdinand is requesting a new loan of 22000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise. This will be the 7th loan taken out by Ferdinand from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand his business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise.

loans.name: Nusrat's Group

texts.en:
Nusrat lives in Jaranwala, which is a small city of Punjab, Pakistan and famous for its agricultural industry. She has been living there in the area of Sultan Park with her family for past 15 years. Her husband is an animal seller. He purchases animals like sheep and goats in their early ages, raises them and sells them to butchers, at a profit. He has been doing this business for past 10 years and he is known for his good services. He also has a buffalo at his home and he uses it to produce milk to community clients. Nusrat is the mother of 2 sons and 3 daughters. Three of them are enrolled in school while the others stay at home. 

Nusrat spends most of her time staying at home and doing her household responsibilities. She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for the improvement of her husband’s business. Through the loan, he will buy sheep and goats that will help him in expanding his business, by selling more animals to butchers on profit. Nusrat is confident that an investment will be profitable for her husband and will help him to provide better facilities for his family. 

Nusrat is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her 2nd loan application. In the previous loan year, she has proven herself as a responsible client who paid her installments on time and never missed a single meeting. 

Note: “In the photo, the lady with a book (called Asasah Passbook) is Nusrat”.

loans.use: To buy animals (sheep and goats) for animal-sales business.

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en: Rebecca B. is 52 years old, married, and has six children. They live in the town of Sto. Niño, South Cotabato. Rebecca and her husband are both farmers. Rice is the primary crop that they plant and harvest. They also raise pigs in their backyard. Rebecca says that she and her husband work hard to provide for their family and sustain their children's education.  Rebecca is requesting a loan, which will be used to purchase fertilizers and pig feed.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and pig feed

loans.name: Fe

texts.en:
Fe S. is married and has one child who attends college.  They live in Tanza, Cavite.  She is one of the community partners of CCT* and aims for a completeness in life.  Fe runs a  wholesale business, which she has had for two years. She sells grocery items and other merchandise in bulk. With an employee helping her with the daily routine tasks, Fe is able to earn an estimated net income of 13,000 PHP every month.

Knowing that there is more to do to improve her business, Fe is requesting a loan for 15,000 PHP.  She intends to buy dividers with which to showcase her products. She will also purchase additional merchandise such as instant noodles, bread, and candles.  This effort goes toward her goal of establishing a grocery.  She works hard for ways to improve her business. It is her desire to manage her time well for her business and church ministry and to manifest excellence in all aspects of her life.  

As a CCT community partner, she faithfully attends the group's weekly fellowship meeting where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God.

*All CCT community partners and clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To purchase dividers to be used as display racks and cabinets for her store

loans.name: Remedios

texts.en: Remedios, a married woman living in the town of Sto. Niño, South Cotabato, has four children, the oldest of whom is 26 years old. Remedios is engaged in both farming and hog-raising business. She mainly manages the fattening of the pigs prior to selling them to the market, while her husband maintains their rice farm. Remedios will use the loan to purchase seeds, fertilizers and feed. She hopes for a better income.

loans.use: to purchase seeds, fertilizers and feed

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en:
Meeting life’s challenges head-on is a habit that could be developed only by the brave. Mercy J., twenty eight, does just like that. Mercy is only a high school graduate but right now she manages her own micro business as she learns entrepreneurship as a community partner in CCT*. She is married to a driver, Romy, and mothers her only child, who is now in high school.

Mercy runs her own sari-sari (variety) store located in an extension of their house. Everyday, she observes the buying patterns of her customers and notes down their preferences in terms of the type of items they buy, the price, and the brand. She sees to it that her customers get what they deserve. Monthly, Mercy earns PHP14,560, on average.

She has applied for a loan worth PHP12,000 to help for the growth of her business. She intends to meet the demands of her customers. As needed, she will buy more stock of rice, soft drinks, and other grocery items. 

Mercy acknowledges that no challenge is too hard to meet. She knows that the Lord will enable her to overcome and uphold the future of both her children and her business. She dreams of making her sari-sari store to grow. 

As a CCT community partner, she faithfully attends the group's weekly fellowship* meeting where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she received.

*All CCT community partners and clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To purchase additional stock for her store, like sacks of rice and  grocery items.

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John has been involved with mixed farming in the central Kenyan Muranga Town for over 30 years. He is married, has six children with one still in schooling and solely relies on farming for his upkeep. His products of milk, beans and maize are sold to the local market. 

John has requested a loan amounting to 70,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to enable him to purchase a water pump and irrigation pipes, all for setting up an irrigation system. He says the equipment will make his production consistent and consequently enable him and his family to live a better life through improved income. He has aspirations to be a leader in farming in his area. 

John says that the biggest challenge that his farming business is facing is fluctuation of market prices. However, he is optimistic that he will be able to repay his loan. He says that, with the funds from Juhudi Kilimo, his life will change tremendously.

loans.use: to purchase irrigation equipment.

loans.name: Victor

texts.en:
Victor P. is from the town of Rizal, Quirino, Isabela. He is 52 years old. Victor is married and has 5 adult children. To make a living, Victor plants and harvests rice for sale. Victor has been engaged in his business for over 19 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2011, Victor joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. Victor has successfully repaid a previous loan of 23,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. Victor is requesting a new loan of 15000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise. This will be the 7th loan taken out by Victor from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand his business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise.

loans.name: Rezyl

texts.en:
Rezyl is a 25-year-old married woman from the town of Sto. Niño, South Cotabato. She has 3 young children aged 5, 3 and 2.

Rezyl is engaged in farming and hog-raising. Her husband, who is also a farmer, mainly manages their rice farm, while she helps weeding when she can. Rezyl makes sure that the pigs she grows are healthy. She also takes good care of her children.

This loan will be used to purchase fertilizers and pig feeds. In the future, Rezyl hopes to have a stable business.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and pig feed.

loans.name: Farzana's Group

texts.en:
Farzana lives in Sultan Park which is located in a city called Jaranwala, Pakistan and known for its agriculture industry. She came here 17 years ago with her family and they live in a 3 roomed brick house. A talented lady, Farzana operates a clothes-selling business to financially assist her husband. It has been going well for her so far and she earns a regular income from this business every month. Her mother in law is also involved with her in this business. Besides her work, she also carries out her responsibilities as a housewife very well.  

Farzana is married to S. A., who has a government job with a reasonable income. Farzana has 2 sons. Both of her sons are enrolled in a local school and are getting their education. She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah to expand her clothes selling business. Loan Investment will help her to buy clothes of greater variety, in bulk. This will also cut her costs of travelling, as she will be bulk purchasing. She started this business 5 years ago and is very hopeful that by investing loan money into her business, she will be able to get good results from it and be successful.  

Farzana is a regular loan user from Asasah and this is her 4th loan application. She has maintained a good credit record in every loan year and never missed any meetings. 

Note: “In the photo, the lady with a book (called Asasah Passbook) is Farzana”.

loans.use: To buy clothes for clothing sales business.

loans.name: Rochelle

texts.en: Rochell, a 41-year-old mother of two children, aged six and four, lives in Sto. Niño, South Cotabato. Married to a farmer, Rochelle earns a living through hog-raising and farming. She helps her husband plant and harvest rice crops and also raises pigs for later sale in their backyard. Rochelle does her best to help sustain her family and will use the loan to purchase fertilizers and other farm inputs. In the future, she hopes to have a profitable business.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and other farm inputs

loans.name: Delia

texts.en:
Delia B. is from the town of Rizal, Quirino, Isabela. She is 41 years old. Delia is married and has two adult children. To make a living, Delia owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Delia has been engaged in her business for over 19 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2011, Delia joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Delia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. Delia is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise. This will be the 7th loan taken out by Delia from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise.

loans.name: Teresa's Group

texts.en:
Teresa C. is from the village of Santor, Reina Mercedes, Isabela. She is 36 years old. Teresa is the group leader of a 7-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Teresa is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Teresa owns & operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from hulled rice retailing. Teresa is just starting this business.

In 2011, Teresa joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Teresa is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional rice to sell. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Teresa from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional rice to sell.

loans.name: Heng

texts.en:
Heng P., age 41, makes a living by selling fish. She buys the fish in bulk from her wholesale supplier and then sells it out for a profit. She currently earns an average of $4 a day, and she has been running her business for a few years. Her husband is 37 years old and is a building worker in the mobile place in Phnom Penh City. She is the mother of two teenage children, who are attending school.

She and her family face difficulties with their living conditions because her house is too small and narrow, so she wants to build a few rooms under her house. She says that she has problems with the financial factor so she cannot do it. This the reason why Heng P. would like to request a loan from Kiva.

loans.use: to build a few rooms under her house

loans.name: Kaneez's Group

texts.en:
Kaneez has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah to expand her grocery business. She operates her business from her home and sells daily household items through her shop. She sells her products at reasonable rates and that’s why people from her community prefer to buy items from her. 

She has been living in Jaranwala for many years with her family in a 2-room brick house. Jaranwala is a small city of Punjab, Pakistan and known for its agriculture industry. Besides her business, she also carries out her responsibilities as a housewife very well. She has given birth to four children. Her eldest son helps her in her business. The 2nd one works n a shoe factory while her daughters stay at home. Due to financial constraints, Kaneez couldn’t educate her children. 

Her husband’s name is A. A. and he sells buffalo milk to his community clients. Kaneez is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is the 4th time she has applied. In previous loan years, she has proved herself to be a responsible client by paying her installments on time and by attending every meeting. She is hopeful that an investment will bring more profits to her and improve her business to great extent. 

Note: In the photo, the lady with a book (called Asasah Passbook) is Kaneez.

loans.use: To buy groceries for her little grocery business.

loans.name: Tomas

texts.en:
Tomas is 35 years old, married, and has three children aged 8, 7 and 6. He works hard to sustain his children's education. He wishes for his children to have bright futures.

Tomas is a farmer working in Sto. Niño, South Cotabato. He owns the land that he tills for planting and harvesting rice crops. His harvest is sold to the market. He has also put up a sari-sari (variety) store that his wife manages. They sell various products such as soft drinks and canned goods.

Tomas's loan will be used to purchase fertilizers and other farm inputs.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and other farm inputs.

loans.name: Glenn's Group

texts.en:
Glenn O. is from the village of Tres Reyes, Saguday, Quirino. She is 25 years old. Glenn is the group leader of a 6-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is "O.'s group".

Glenn is married and has one infant child. To make a living, Glenn owns & operates a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Glenn has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 1500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2011, Glenn joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Glenn is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Glenn from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Rasheeda's Group

texts.en:
Rasheeda has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband who wants to expand his shoe-making business. With the loan, he will purchase leather, shoe buckles and shoe laces which will allow him to manufacture a larger number of shoes and earn better profits. He started this business five years ago. He takes orders from different shoe shops and factories. 

Rasheeda is a housewife as well as a seamstress. She stays at home and does her household chores. Then she uses her sewing skills to sew beautiful clothes for her neighboring clients and earns well from it.  She has given birth to two sons and a daughter.  All of them are still young and enrolled in a local school. 

She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her 3rd loan application. In previous loan years, she has paid her installments on time and never missed a single meeting. She is hopeful that an investment will bring good changes to her husband’s business and increase his profits. 

She lives in Jaranwala which is a small city in Punjab Pakistan, known for its agriculture industry. She has been living there in the area of Sultan park with her family in a single-room brick house for the past 14 years. 

Note: In the photo, the lady with a book (called Asasah Passbook) is Rasheeda.

loans.use: To buy leather, shoe buckles, and shoe laces for making shoes.

loans.name: Felicitas Pacion's Group

texts.en:
Felicitas P. is from the village of Bantay Solana, Cagayan. She is 40 years old. Felicitas is the group leader of a 5-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is  "Felicitas P.'s Group".

Felicitas is married and has five school-aged children. To make a living, Felicitas owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for fattening and sale. Felicitas has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 4000 PHP when she sells one of her raised pigs.

In 2011, Felicitas joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Felicitas is requesting a loan of 4000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Felicitas from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase livestock feed & other supplies

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more spare parts for radios and TVs, and more electronic tools for her husband’s business.

loans.name: Gemma's Group

texts.en:
Gemma Y. is from the village of Tandul, Cabatuan, Isabela. She is 37 years old. Gemma is the group leader of a 8-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Gemma is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Gemma owns & operates a business venture in the food sector running a food stall. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from tending a canteen near the school. Gemma has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 8000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Gemma joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Gemma has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Gemma is requesting a new loan of 25,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional ingredients to cook more dishes and snacks to sell. This will be the 7th loan taken out by Gemma from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional ingredients to cook more dishes and snacks to sell.

loans.name: Anita

texts.en:
Anita is 40 years old, married and has five children. Her oldest child is 17 years old. Her husband works as a farmer.

Anita is also a farmer. She and her husband till their land and prepares it well for planting rice crops. Anita has been engaged in farming for more than 17 years and earns approximately PHP 3500 per month.

Anita's loan will be used to purchase fertilizers and other farm inputs.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and other farm inputs.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Bashiran's Group

texts.en:
Bashiran, who resides in Jaranwala, a small city of Punjab Pakistan known for its agriculture industry, has been living with her family in a two-room brick house in the area called Sultan Park for the past three years. Having given birth to two sons, neither of whom is yet old enough to attend school, she spends her time at home discharging her household responsibilities.

Bashiran's husband operates an animal-selling business, purchasing and raising young goats and sheep and then selling them to butchers for profit. Bashiran has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband to buy more goats and sheep, confident that the investment will enable his business to grow.

A regular loan user of Asasah, this is Bashiran's fourth loan application. She is a responsible client and has a good credit record.

Note: In the photo, the lady with a book (called Asasah Passbook) is Bashiran.

loans.use: to buy goats and sheep for her husband's animal-sales business

loans.name: Erdenebold

texts.en:
Erdenebold is 48 years old, a father of 5 children and lives with his wife and four children in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. They all live together in small house on their plot of land. His oldest son Narankhuu 24 is a student and currently living separately from the family, with his wife. His other four children are attending a local secondary school. 

Erdenebold has been operating a taxi service in city for the past seven years and has gained many experiences. He is a very hardworking person with a strong will, who is responsible his children’s living expenses and teaching them good morals. In the future he is planning to get newer car with his savings. 

Erdenebold is requesting a loan to buy a Ger, the traditional Mongolian nomadic tent, and furniture for his oldest son.

loans.use: to buy a ''Ger", the traditional Mongolian tent.

loans.name: Divina

texts.en:
39-year-old Divina is a married woman who has 7 children. The oldest child is 19 years old.

Divina is a farmer working in Surallah, South Cotabato. She has been growing rice for more than 19 years. She earns approximately 4500 per month doing this farming.

Divina's loan will be used to purchase fertilizers, seeds and other farm inputs. In the future, Divina hopes for a successful business.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers, seeds and other farm inputs.

loans.name: Chheng

texts.en:
Chheng V. is married and resides with her husband in Takeo province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-angkorean temples. V. produces traditional baskets to sell, earning an income of USD 3 per day. Her husband is employed at a rubber farm, earning an income of USD 5 per day. 

Each month, the family has to spend USD 42 on food and USD 35 on the other necessary expenses. V. is requesting a loan of USD 500 to repair her house. 

In the future, she would like to use the additional income to continue to repair her house. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a long standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: to repair the house.

loans.name: Mom

texts.en:
Mom P. is married and resides with her husband in Takeo province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-angkorean temples. P. and her husband produce small wooden houses to sell, earning an income of USD 4 each per day. Each month, the family has to spend USD 42 on food and USD 35 on the other necessary expenses. 

P. is requesting a loan of USD 500 to pay for the children’s school fees. In the future, she would like to use the additional income to repair her house. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a long standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: to pay for the children's school fees.

loans.name: Sum

texts.en:
Sum S. is a firewood seller who is 38 years old, and is a married father caring for three children who are pupils in the local public school. Sum S. has been selling firewood since 2002, earning a profit of approximately $6.40 each day to help support the family's expenses. His wife makes a living by raising pigs in a cage behind their house. 

Presently, Sum S. uses his old motorcyle as a vehicle to transport his firewood to sell in and around his community in Kompong Tom province. Unluckily, his motorcycle broke down during the process. The couple wishes to buy a new one, but they don’t have sufficient cash to make that possible. In order to deal with this trouble, Sum S. is requesting a loan which will be used to buy a new motorcycle to replace the broken one.

loans.use: to buy a new motorcycle to replace the broken one

loans.name: Yvette

texts.en:
Yvette is 36 years old, and she is married with one child who is two years old. Yvette owns a small business selling various styles of African clothes for women. This business is well known and organized. The hours of her business are from 6am until 7pm every day. She has two years of experience in this business.

Yvette has requested her first loan from Kiva lenders, via Vision Finance Company, in order to expand her business by purchasing more African clothes to sell. Once this expansion is reached, Yvette will be able to earn more profit. She wants her business to be wholesale. With any profits, she will build her own house and reinvest in her business.

loans.use: to purchase more African clothes to sell.

loans.name: Josephine's Group

texts.en:
Josephine C. is from the village of Buenavista, Oroquieta city. She is 37 years old. Josephine is the group leader of a 2-member group loan offered by GDMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Josephine is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Josephine owns & operates a specialized retail store, selling delicacies of food in the local community. Josephine has been engaged in her business for over 9 years and earns approximately 2000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2011, Josephine joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Josephine is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the first loan taken out by Josephine from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business.

loans.name: Edmarie

texts.en: Edmarie D. is 45 years old, married, and has three children ages 21, 19, and 17. Edmarie is a farmer working in Surallah, South Cotabato. She and her husband work together tilling and preparing their land.  Rice is the primary crop that they plant and harvest.  Edmarie says she and her husband work hard to increase their harvest.  Edmarie is requesting a loan, which will be used to purchase rice seeds and fertilizers. In the future, she wishes to be a successful entrepreneur.

loans.use: To purchase rice seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret is a farmer in Kitale Town, in Western Kenya. She has been practicing mixed farming for twenty years, producing and selling milk, vegetables and maize and selling to the local market. She is married and has six children, aged between 4 and 20 years. Farming is her source of income.

Margaret has requested for a loan of 36,400 KES from Juhudi Kilimo,a Kiva partner, to purchase and insure a dairy cow. She is looking forward to saving the income generated from the dairy cow to pay for her children's education. She also on wants to acquire another dairy cow in the near future. She believes dairy farming will make life much better.

Margaret, however, sees animals' diseases as the greatest challenge to the business due to high costs incurred in treatment.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Sreng

texts.en:
Sreng P., 34, is married and resides with her husband in Phnom Penh City, Cambodia, an area known as the most populated city in the country. P. sells vegetables and meat, earning an income of USD 10 per day to help cover the family's expenses. 

Each month, the family has to spend USD 150 on food and USD 45 on the other necessary expenses. P. is requesting a loan of USD 1000 to purchase more vegetables and meat to stock the store. In the future, she would like to use the additional income to repair her house. This will be her second loan from CREDIT, a long standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: to buy more vegetables and meat to resell.

location.town: Mean Chey District, Phnom Penh City

loans.name: Orn

texts.en:
The woman shown in the picture is Orn R., age 34, a married woman who currently lives in Kompong Tom province. She earns a living by raising pigs in a pigpen behind her house. She raises them both for their offspring and for slaughter. In addition, she also cultivates a rice crop, while her husband earns as a firewood seller. They have four children, three of whom are single and the other one is married. 

Orn R. is seeking a loan to buy two buffalo to be used by her husband to transport firewood to sell in the local market. The buffalo can also be used for breeding purposes, so they can also raise the offspring.

loans.use: To buy two buffalo to be used by her husband to transport firewood to sell

loans.name: Munkhzaya

texts.en:
Munkhzaya is a 38-year-old woman who trained as a professional cook. She lives with her husband and two kids in a ‘ger’ (Mongolian traditional felt tent) in a suburb of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Her husband has a seasonal job, from April to October, at summer camp called Gachuurt. Her 5-year-old daughter goes to kindergarten and her 14-year-old son attends public secondary school. 

Munkhzaya was working on her career from 1992 to 1996. She started the clothing sales business in 2007, with working capital of 500,000 MNT (Mongolian Tugriks) at Narantuul, the largest outdoor market of Mongolia. She sells used clothes which are imported from Korean or Chinese wholesale suppliers. The business profitability is constantly stable since selling used clothing is a business that can help earn money but also it offers a valuable service to the community. Today, Munkhzaya’s business has expanded so that her working capital is 2,500,000 MNT and she bought one more stall at the market with the profits. 

She is requesting a loan of 2,000,000 MNT to purchase more used clothes to expand the business, since she is running two stalls at the same time. She is planning to build a new small house in the future with the business profits, where her family can enjoy better living conditions.
