loans.use: To purchase more clothes to expand the business.

loans.name: Soy

texts.en:
Soy S. is married and resides with her husband in Siem Reap province, Cambodia, an area known for Angkorean temples. S. sells groceries, earning an income of USD 4 each per day. Her husband is a tuk-tuk driver, earning an income of USD 7 each per day. 

Each month, the family has to spend USD 90 on food and USD 25 on the other necessary expenses. S. is requesting a loan of USD 500 to purchase a new motorbike for her husband to improve his business. In the future, she would like to use the additional income to repair her house. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a long standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for her husband, to improve his business.

loans.name: Pelex

texts.en: Pelex is a twenty-seven year old, hardworking man living in a rented house in Fort Portal Uganda longing to build his own house. He has been in construction for three years and, with the income, he was able to pay school fees for his siblings. Pelex needs the loan to buy land.

loans.use: to buy land.

loans.name: Rehana's Group

texts.en:
Rehana lives in a small city of Punjab Pakistan called Kasur. it is famous for its leather industry. She has been living in a 3-roomed brick house with her family in the area of Kot Fateh Baz Khan for the past 18 years. 

Rehana is an embroidery expert and does embroidery on clothes for her neighboring customers. She has a good name in the region due to her ability to produce quality work. She receives regular orders every month, which earns her good income. She uses this income to pay utility bills. Her husband, M. I., operates an herbal medicines business. He has good knowledge about herbs and, not only treats the patients, but also sells the medicines to those who do this business in different cities. 

Rehana is the mother of 7 children. Her eldest son is 17 years old. He left his education after 5th level and started doing work. He operates a power loom machine and manufactures clothes. Her elder daughter helps Rehana in the embroidery business. The daughter is going through with the learning process and, after some months, will be handling it independently. The other 3 children are enrolled in a local school and are getting their education and remain living at home. 

Rehana has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for the improvement of her husband’s business. Through the loan, he will buy larger quantities of herbs for making medicines to treat his patients better. Rehana is hopeful that the loan will help her husband increase his profits and serve more patients. 

Rehana is a new loan user and this is her first loan application to Asasah. 

Note: “In the photo, the lady with a book (called Asasah Passbook) is Rehana”.

loans.use: To buy herbs for herbal medicines business.

loans.name: Elena

texts.en:
Elena is 50 years old, married and has three children. The oldest child is 27 years old.

Elena is a farmer and hog-grower. She has been growing rice for more than 20 years. She earns PHP 5000 per month from rice farming. She also grows pigs in her backyard. She fattens the pigs and sells them to the market.

Elena requested a loan which she will use to purchase farm fertilizers and pig feed.

loans.use: to purchase farm fertilizers and pig feed.

loans.name: Pov

texts.en:
Pov S. is married and resides with her husband in Siem Reap province, Cambodia, an area known for Angkorean temples. S. sells groceries, earning an income of USD 7 per day. Her child is employed at a hotel, earning an income of USD 5 per day. Each month, the family has to spend USD 70 on food and USD 90 on other necessary expenses. 

S. is requesting a loan of USD 1000 to purchase a new motorbike for her child to use to commute to work. In the future, she would like to use any additional income to repair her house. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: to buy a motorbike for her child to use to commute to work.

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah is a thirty-eight-year-old married woman with three children living in her own semi-permanent house in Fort Portal, Uganda. Her desire is to construct a permanent house and educate her children. She runs a crafts shop and has been in this business for six years. She has been able to meet daily family needs and also pay school fees. The only hindrance is that the business is seasonal and her dream is to start an art gallery. 

Sarah needs the loan facility to buy craft items for resale.

loans.use: to buy crafts for resale.

loans.name: Elenita

texts.en:
42-year-old Elenita grows rice for a living. She lives in the town of Surallah, South Cotabato with her family. Elenita has been growing rice for quite some time now. She says farming is the first and main source of income of her family. Elenita set aside some money from farming and used it to put up a sari-sari (variety) store. According to her, the store helps in their daily needs.

Elenita requested a loan that she will use to purchase seeds and fertilizers. She hopes to have a successful business in the future.

loans.use: to purchase seeds and fertilizers.

loans.name: Mi

texts.en:
Mi N. is married and resides with her husband in Siem Reap province, Cambodia, an area known for Angkorean temples. N. grows cassava, earning an income of USD 12 per day. Her husband is a construction worker, earning an income of USD 5 per day. Each month, the family has to spend USD 82 on food and USD 50 on other necessary expenses. 

N. is requesting a loan of USD 500 to hire people to plow the farm in order grow more cassava. In the future, she would like to use the additional income to repair her house. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: to hire people to help plow the farm.

loans.name: Pheun

texts.en:
Pheun S. is 40 years old and has been selling a few fresh fish in the busy local market for more than ten years. She and her husband buy fish from their wholesale supplier and from fishermen in the rural areas at a reasonable price, and then they hurry up to bring their fresh fish to sell. 

They are running their business well because they have skills in public relations which they use with their customers. The family typically generates a revenue of about $10.80 each day for covering the family’s expenses. The humble couple has four children who are enrolled in school. 

In order to earn more profit, Pheun S. is applying for a loan to purchase additional fish in large amounts for resale.

loans.use: to purchase fish in large amounts for resale

loans.name: C4903 Inshuti Group

texts.en:
Gilbert is the president of a group called “Inshuti”, which has a total of five members, Gilbert is the first person on the left in the photo. He owns a small business for selling sugar, rice, bananas, sorghum, etc. He is 26 years old and is married with two children and three additional dependents who are relatives. His business is open from 6am until 10pm every day. This is his third successful year in his business.

Gilbert and his group will use this loan to purchase more products to sell, such as salt, beans, soft drinks, bread etc. With any profit, Gilbert would like to provide food for his family, pay school fees for his dependents, renovate his house and save money for the future.

loans.use: to purchase more products to sell, like salt, beans, bread, and so on

loans.name: Eric

texts.en:
Eric is a 31-year-old married man with 2 young children. He lives in the town of Surallah, South Cotabato with his family.

Eric is a farmer. He plants and harvests rice crops. Eric just finished preparing his land and is now ready for planting rice crops. He has requested a loan which he will use to purchase fertilizers and seeds. Eric hopes for an increased harvest.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and seeds.

loans.name: Tin

texts.en:
Tin T. is married and resides with his wife in Siem Reap province, Cambodia, an area known for Angkorean temples. T. is a construction foreman, earning an income of USD 6 per day. Each month, the family has to spend USD 83 on food and USD 50 on the other necessary expenses. 

T. is requesting a loan of USD 1000 to purchase cows in order to transport firewood to sell. In the future, he would like to use the additional income to repair his house. This will be his first loan from CREDIT, a long standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: to buy cows to transport firewood to resell.

loans.name: Diana

texts.en: Diana is currently in a business of selling ice cream. she is 26 years old, married to a businessman, with 2 children, none of them go to school. Diana borrowed a loan to stock more ice cream to sell.Her future goal is to build a shop with extra profits from her business.

loans.use: stock more ice cream to sell.

loans.name: Pean

texts.en:
Pean T. is married and resides with her husband in Siem Reap province, Cambodia, an area known for Angkorean temples. T. sells souvenirs at the temples, earning an income of USD 10 per day. Her husband uses his horse for the tourists to ride, earning an income of USD 7 per day. Each month, the family has to spend USD 37 on food and USD 100 on the other necessary expenses. 

T. is requesting a loan of USD 1200 to purchase a camera to take photos of the tourists and to build public sanitation for the tourists. In the future, she would like to use the additional income to repair her house. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a long standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: To buy a camera and to build public sanitation.

loans.name: Josiane

texts.en:
Josiane is 29 years old. She is married with four children between the ages of one and nine. She owns a business selling bananas and onions. Her business is open from 7am until 8pm every day. She has four years of experience in this business and she is currently employs one person to help her. 

Josiane has requested a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company for the purpose of increasing her business by purchasing more bananas and onions to satisfy her customers. With any profits, she will pay school fees for her children and save for her future.

loans.use: to purchase more bananas and onions to sell

loans.name: Everlyne

texts.en:
Everlyne is married with six children aged between twenty-six and eight. She has been in mixed farming for ten years in her hometown of Kitale in Western Kenya, producing maize, beans and milk which she sells locally. She engages the services of one farmhand in her farm. She earns additional income from her clothing retail business.

Everlyne has requested a loan of 31,200 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. She is optimistic she will be able to pay for her children's education from the dairy income as well as improve their overall standard of living.

Everlyne  laments that poor prices caused by unstable markets are a great threat to farming businesses.

loans.use: to purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Rat

texts.en:
Rat S. is a 61-year-old farmer who lives in Kompong Cham province. She is married to Mr. Sokchea, age 41, who works with her in the farming business. She inherited the farmland from her grandmother, where she and her husband grow different kinds of crops. This is the time for plowing the dry-season rice field, but she doesn’t have the funds to plow her farmland yet. 

Because of this reason, Rat S. will use the loan to hire a few domestic laborers to plow on their farmland so she can start to grow her rice crop on time. 

The couple is blessed with six children, three of whom are single and work at a garment industry, while the other three are married and live in their own houses.

loans.use: to hire a few domestic laborers to plow their farmland.

loans.name: Safia's Group

texts.en:
Safia is a very supportive lady by nature and belongs to Kamoki, which is a small city of Punjab, Pakistan, famous for its agriculture industry.  She has been living there in the area of Bilal Park in a 4-room house with her family for the past 20 years. 

Her husband whose name is M. S. is a milk man by profession. He milks the buffalo, getting up early in the morning. Safia helps him by putting the milk into milk jars.  He sells the milk to his community clients. 

Safia is also a very good housewife and fulfills her responsibilities very well. She has given birth to one son who is an embroidery expert. Safia couldn’t provide him education due to financial constraints. He operates his embroidery shop in the market and earns good profits from it. 

Safia has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah to help her husband in his business. With the loan, he will buy another buffalo to increase the productivity of milk so he can sell to more people. Safia is hopeful that the loan investment will further improve his milk sales business. 

She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her 4th loan application. In previous loan years, she has proved herself as a responsible client who always paid her installments on time and never missed a single meeting. 

Note: In the photo, the lady with a book (called Asasah Passbook) is Safia.

loans.use: To buy another buffalo for milk sales business.

loans.name: Florita

texts.en:
Florita is 64 years old and married with nine children. The oldest child is 47 years old. 

Florita is a farmer working in Surallah, South Cotabato. She grows rice that she sells to the community. Florita currently earns approximately 3500 PHP per month. She works hard to improve this income.

This loan will be used to purchase rice seeds and fertilizers. In the future, Florita hopes to have a stable business.

loans.use: to purchase rice seeds and fertilizers.

loans.name: Paska

texts.en: Paska J. is currently in the business of selling ice-cream. She is 30 years old, married to a businessman, and she has four children. Only one is not going to school. Paska borrowed a loan to stock more ice-cream. Her future goal is to open a supermarket.

loans.use: to stock more  ice cream to sell.

loans.name: Gleceria

texts.en:
Gleceria, 52 years old, is a married woman. She has two children aged 29 and 25.

Gleceria is a farmer. She tills her land in the town of Surallah, South Cotabato. She grows rice that she sells to the market. Gleceria also grows ducks and sells their eggs. Gleceria works hard to improve her family's living conditions.

This loan will be used to purchase fertilizers and other farm inputs.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and other farm inputs.

loans.name: Robert

texts.en: Robert is a thirty five year old married man. He has three children and the family is living in his own house in Fort Portal, Uganda. For four years he has been operating a retail shop and with the income earned, he has been able to provide for the family. He has the challenge of limited funds to meet consumer demands. His dream is to become a wholesale trader. Robert needs the loan facilities to buy bread, sugar and rice to resell.

loans.use: to purchase bread, sugar and rice to sell.

loans.name: Bayarmaa

texts.en:
Bayarmaa is 37 years old lives with her husband and a daughter in Darkhan city, Mongolia. They live in small house on their plot of land. Her daughter is 5 years old and attends a local kindergarten. Her husband works at “Erel Tsement” LLC as a plumber. 

In 2009 Bayarmaa decided to rent a place and open a small grocery shop. Since then, she has been running her business quite successfully. So, she decided to build her own small shop and, at same time, to increase her working capital and profit. Sometimes she stays at her store overnight to protect her store from theft. She is planning to expand her business by selling vodka and beer at her store. The building work is 75 % complete. The reason she is requesting a loan is to complete the building project.

loans.use: to complete the building project at her store.

loans.name: Dahlia Taguinod's Group

texts.en:
Dahlia T. is from the village of Sampaguita Solana, Cagayan. She is 45 years old. Dahlia is the group leader of a 5-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Dahlia T.'s Group.

Dahlia is married and has 2 adult children. To make a living, Dahlia owns & operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. Dahlia has been engaged in her business for over 21 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2011, Dahlia joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Dahlia is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand product offering. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Dahlia from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase new items to expand product offering.

loans.name: Tabitha

texts.en:
Tabitha T., 38 years old, is currently in the business of selling alcohol. She is married to a businessman and they have nine children. Four of the children are going to school. 

Her future goal is to own a shop.

loans.use: to stock more alcohol.

loans.name: Choam

texts.en:
Choam S. is married and resides with his wife in Siem Reap province, Cambodia, an area known for Angkorean temples. S. buys used motorbikes to resell, earning an income of USD 8 per day. 

Each month, the family has to spend USD 83 on food and USD 50 on the other necessary expenses. 

S. is requesting a loan of USD 600 to purchase motorbikes to resell. In the future, he would like to use the additional income to repair his house. This will be his first loan from CREDIT, a long standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: To buy motorbikes to resell.

loans.name: Boldbaatar

texts.en:
Mr. Boldbaatar is 49 years old and lives with his wife and two daughters in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. His family currently live in rented flat. 

Boldbaatar used to travel to the countryside to buy raw cashmere from herders and sell it to cashmere processing factories. In 2010 he bought a cashmere knitting machine and started producing cashmere products such as jumpers, sweaters, hats, scarfs and so on. Currently he employs four workers and besides making products, he also does dry cleaning for cashmere products. 

Lately he started renting a stall inside the garment store and to sell his products to buyers directly. These kinds of products are very warm and light and they are in big demand in wintertime in Mongolia. 

Boldbaatar is requesting a loan to buy 14 kilos of cashmere thread to supply his production. A bundle of 1 kilo thread costs around 150 USDs.

loans.use: To buy 14 kilos of cashmere thread to produce clothing.

loans.name: Marie Claire

texts.en:
Marie Claire is 31 years old and she is married. Marie Claire sells charcoal and her business is well-organized. She employs one person to help her and she works from 8am until 7pm every day. She has one year's experience in her business.

Marie Claire has requested a loan from Kiva lenders in order to purchase more sacks of charcoal for sale. With any profits, Marie Claire will reinvest in her business, satisfy her customers, and save for her future.

loans.use: To purchase more sacks of charcoal.

loans.name: Tep

texts.en:
Tep R. is married and resides with his wife in Siem Reap province, Cambodia, an area known for Angkorean temples. R. is a construction foreman, earning an income of USD 10 per day. Each month, the family has to spend USD 83 on food and USD 50 on other necessary expenses. 

R. is requesting a loan of USD 300 to purchase fish food to raise fish. In the future, he would like to use any additional income to repair his house. This will be his first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: buy fish food to raise fish

loans.name: God's Grace Group

texts.en:
This is the second loan that Munda and his group members have applied for from SMT/Kiva lenders. With the help of their previous Kiva loan, they were be able to expand their businesses, make more sales, and consequently improve their living conditions. Having completed repaying their previous loan successfully, they are again requesting a new loan of SLL 3,100,000 in order to further expand their businesses. 

Munda T. is the leader of this group of entrepreneurs. Born thirty-nine years ago in the town of Matru Johng, Munda is married and has five children.  For four years now, Munda has been selling house-building materials – cement, iron-rods, paint, etc. Munda will use his share of the loan (SLL 800,000) to expand his business; he will buy house-building materials in large quantity to add to his business inventory.

loans.use: Buy house-building materials in large quantity to add to his business inventory.

loans.name: Dolores' Group

texts.en:
Dolores M. is from the village of Liwliwa, Angadanan, Isabela. She is 53 years old. Dolores is the group leader of a 10-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Dolores is married and has seven adult children. To make a living, Dolores owns & operates a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Dolores is just starting this business.

In 2011, Dolores joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Dolores is requesting a loan of 7000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Dolores from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more groceries to stock the store

loans.name: Jean Paul

texts.en:
Jean Paul is 29 years old and married with two children, ages 3 and 5. Jean Paul has been a motorbike taxi driver for three years. He transports people every day from 5am until 11pm.

Jean Paul has requested a loan from Kiva lenders in order to buy a new motorbike to help him. With any profit, he will pay school fees for his children  and save for his future.

loans.use: To buy a new motorbike

loans.name: Astta

texts.en: Astta B. is Currently in a business of selling vegetables. She's 44 years old and married to a businessman. They have four children, two of whom are going to school. Her future goal is to build a house.

loans.use: to stock more charchoies

loans.name: Helen

texts.en:
Helen is 50 years old, married, and has 4 children. Helen is a farmer. She grows rice that she sells to her community. Aside from rice farming, Helen also grows pigs and ducks. She sells the pigs and the duck eggs at the market. Helen works hard to help provide for the increasing needs in her household.

Helen requested a loan of 20,000 Philippine pesos, which she will use to purchase fertilizer and other farm inputs. She is hoping her harvest will increase.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer and other farm inputs

loans.name: Lovella

texts.en:
29-year-old Lovella is a married woman from the town of Surallah, South Cotabato. She has a 3-year-old child. Her husband works as a farmer and a driver.

Lovella is also a farmer. She has been growing rice for 3 years. She earns 5,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) per month from growing and selling rice.

Lovella has requested a loan of 10,000 Philippine pesos (PHP), which she will use to purchase fertilizer and other farm inputs. She is hopeful that this loan will help increase her harvest.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer and other farm inputs

loans.name: Claire

texts.en: Claire is a twenty-four-year old single mother of two children living in a rented house in Fort Portal, Uganda, and longs to build her own house. She has been selling second-hand clothes for two years and the business is very profitable despite the challenges of season and limited funds. Claire intends to use the credit facility to buy salt, sugar, and soap.

loans.use: to buy salt, sugar, and soap for resale

loans.name: Tai

texts.en:
Tai V. is a 56-year-old married woman and a local villager living in Kompong Cham province. She has a piece of farmland that she inherited many years ago from her grandparents. She uses this land to grow different kinds of crops at least two times a year, according to rainy season and dry season. She and her husband have been getting good results from growing crops. 

They have given birth to four children. All of them are employed in different jobs, and they always share their profits with their parents to use on the daily expenses. Tai V.’s children are concerned because they face difficulties in traveling to their workplace. They always travel to work by hiring a taxi, as they don't have their own vehicle. To encourage her children, Tai V. has requested a loan in the amount of $800 to be used to buy a motorcycle to provide transportation without hiring a taxi.

loans.use: to buy a motorcycle for her kids to ride to their workplace

loans.name: Ma. Luzviminda

texts.en:
Ma. Luzviminda is a married woman from the town of Surallah, South Cotabato. She is 43 years old and has 4 children. The oldest child is 16 years old. Three of her children go to school. Ma. Luzviminda does her best to sustain their education.

Ma. Luzviminda is engaged in farming. She grows and sells rice. She wishes to put up a sari-sari store to earn an extra income.

This loan will be used to purchase fertilizer and other farm supplies.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer and other farm supplies

loans.name: Marivel

texts.en:
Marivel M. is from the village of Pinamulaan, Banisilan, Cotabato. She is 32 years old. Marivel is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Marivel owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, canned goods, snack foods, detergents & instant noodles in the local community. Marivel has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Marivel joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marivel has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Marivel is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional canned goods, snack foods & beverages to sell. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Marivel from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional canned goods, snack foods & beverages to sell.

loans.name: Esther

texts.en: Esther is currently in a business of selling tea. She is 40 years old, married to a driver,with no children.Esther borrowed a loan to stock more tea to sell. Her future goal is to open a shop with extra profits from her business.

loans.use: stock more tea to sell.

loans.name: Amgalan

texts.en:
Amgalan, age 47, lives with her husband and 6-year-old granddaughter in a ‘ger’ (Mongolian traditional felt tent) in a suburb of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Her husband, Altangadas, helps her to run the business and her granddaughter attends local primary school.  

Amgalan is a professional shoemaker. She was retrained in a shoe-making specialty in the Czech Republic, from 1985 to 1986. She was working on her career until 2000 and later she started to run her own business at Narantuul, the largest outdoor market of Mongolia. Amgalan manufactures curtains, felt covers (for Mongolian ger) and kids’ shoes at home and sells them at Narantuul. The business profitability is relatively high during the spring and summer seasons. Today, she has working capital of 3,000,000 MNT (Mongolian Tugriks) and hopes to increase it in the future. 

She is requesting a loan of 1,000,000 MNT to purchase more materials to make curtains and felt covers. By doing so, she can increase the number of products to she has available to sell which will later help to develop the business. Her aim is to have her own large capacity workshop where she can manufacture more products.

loans.use: to purchase more materials to make curtains and felt covers.

loans.name: Stephen

texts.en: Stephen is a fifty-one-year-old married man with six children living in his own house in Fort Portal, Uganda. He runs a retail shop and in three years he has been able to increase his inventory. He started with 500,000/= working capital and now it is worth 2,000,000/=. He dreams of owning a supermarket despite challenges in finances. Stephen needs the loan to buy rice, paraffin, and soap for resale.

loans.use: to buy rice, paraffin, and soap for resale.

loans.name: Margilyn

texts.en:
Margilyn G. is from the village of Tumbao, Banisilan, South Cotabato. She is 36 years old. Margilyn is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Margilyn owns & operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling canned goods, snack foods & vegetables such as string beans, radishes, etc. in the local community. Margilyn has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Margilyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Margilyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Margilyn is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional snack foods & vegetables like carrots & eggplants. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Margilyn from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional snack foods & vegetables like carrots & eggplants.

loans.name: Evariste

texts.en:
Evariste is 29 years old and married with two children between the ages of 3 and 5. He has been a motorbike taxi driver for 6 months. He transports people every day from 6am until 12pm.

Evariste has requested a loan from Kiva lenders in order to buy essential materials for his motorbike. With any profit, he will pay school fees for his children and save for his future.

loans.use: To buy essential materials for his motorbike

loans.name: Marjorie

texts.en:
Marjorie Q. is from the village of Kabatangan, Wao, Lanao del Sur. She is 28 years old. Marjorie is married and has 1 infant child. To make a living, Marjorie owns & operates a motorela or habal-habal service with as her husband as the driver to local community members. Marjorie has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 7000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Marjorie joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Marjorie has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase materials needed to provide service. Marjorie is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to purchase tools needed for the maintenance of the service. This will be the 4th loan taken out by Marjorie from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Yi

texts.en: Yi T., aged 31, is a fisherman. He usually fishes for eight hours a day in and around the river in Kompong Cham province. He catches around 10 kilos of fish each day and sells them in bulk to his customers who are retail sellers in the market. His wife’s name is Sothea; she is 25 and earns a living by growing rice crops on her own farmland. The couple is blessed with two young children who are enrolled in school. Yi T. will use his loan to repair his house, which is getting old and broken. Yi T. and his wife are pictured in the photo.

loans.use: to repair his house, which is getting old and broken

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 45-year-old Lebanese married man living with his wife and three school-age children. He's owned a bakery since 1995 and has 16 years of experience working as a baker. He prepares delicious fresh goods. He works hard to be able to pay for his family's expenses, especially for his children's schooling. He has obtained three Kiva loans and is an excellent client with payments on time. 

Today, he is requesting to borrow $1200 from Kiva's partner, Ameen s.a.l., to purchase flour and gas for his bakery in order to increase his productivity. In the long term, he is planning to continue expansion of his business. He is positive about his future plans.

loans.use: to purchase flour and gas for his bakery.

loans.name: Melinda

texts.en:
Melinda is a 44-year-old married woman living in the town of Surallah, South Cotabato. She is engaged in farming. She grows rice that she sells to her community. Rice farming is the only source of income for Melinda's family. She works hard to maintain the farm's productivity.

Melinda has requested for a loan of PHP 12000, which she will use to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs. She is hopeful that this loan will help to improve her harvest.

loans.use: to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs.

loans.name: Eleonor

texts.en:
Eleonor P. is from the village of Eastern, Wao, Lanao del Sur. She is 34 years old. Eleonor is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Eleonor owns & operates a tailoring business, providing general alteration or upholstery & tailoring services to local community members. Eleonor has been engaged in her business for over 6 years and earns approximately 10000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Eleonor joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 9000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional tailoring equipment such as needles & thread. Eleonor is requesting a new loan of 11000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional fabrics & materials. This will be the 5th loan taken out by Eleonor from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.name: Kahuna B Group

texts.en:
Raphar is a sixty three year old married woman. She has three children, living in her own house in Fort Portal, Uganda.

For six years, Raphar has been involved in a retail business after diverting from the sale of fresh foods, which were perishable. She has the challenge of limited funds in order to meet the demands of her customers and her desire is to become a wholesale trader. 

Raphar needs the loan facility to buy maize, flour, sanitary towels and salt for resale.

loans.use: to buy maize flour, sanitary towels and salt for resale.

loans.name: Remia

texts.en:
Remia B. is from the village of Eastern Wao, Lanao del Sur. She is 55 years old, married, and has four adult children. To make a living, Remia owns and operates a a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from buying and selling dried fish such as dilis, pinikas, and sari in the local community. Remia has been engaged in her business for over six years and earns approximately 15,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Remia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Remia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 12,000 PHP from HSPFI, which was used to to purchase additional inventory and acquire working capital. Remia is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional dried fish to sell such as pinikas and ulang. This loan will be Remia's seventh loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.name: Srey

To earn a living, Srey H. sells items such as pork, beef and some vegetables in the busy market, in Siem Reap province. She typically makes around $3 each day to cover her family expenses. Srey H. will use her loan as a capital to buy additional meat and vegetables for selling. This will allow her to gain more income for supporting her family. In this way, she will be able to improve her family's standard of living.

loans.name: Buhara Group United

loans.name: Rhoda

texts.en:
Rhoda is a married woman who lives in the town of Surallah, South Cotabato, with her family. She has 3 children, the oldest of whom is 17 years old.

Rhoda is a farmer. She plants and harvests rice crops that she sells to the market. Aside from rice farming, she also raises pigs. She fattens the pigs and sells them to the market.

This loan will be used to purchase seeds, fertilizers and feeds.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
The Kiva borrower is a 24-year-old single man from Lebanon. He lives on his own. He has been working as a wood painter for five years. He works on a freelance basis. He is good at his job and has many customers asking for his services. With his business income, he is able to satisfy his needs. 
Today, he is requesting to borrow $1,200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase new painting tools. These purchases will allow him to present better quality services to the clients. In the future, he hopes to further expand his business and continue his work properly to earn higher income.

loans.use: to purchase new painting tools

loans.name: Yonni Traders Group

texts.en:
Salone Microfinance Trust (SMT), a partner of Kiva.org, in Makeni, northern Sierra Leone, is very pleased to present to you members of the “Yonni Traders” group. These are small scale entrepreneurs who have come to SMT/Kiva lenders to seek a loan of SLL 1,800,000.00 in order to invest in their businesses. 

Hawa K. is the leader of this group. Hawa is 34 years old and married, with 2 children – 1 in primary school and 1 in secondary school. Hawa sells cooked rice, meat and vegetables. With the help of this loan,  Hawa will invest in her business by buying cooking ingredients - rice, palm-oil, margi (used to give sauce a sweet taste), fish, etc, in large quantities.

loans.use: to buy cooking ingredients: rice, palm-oil, margi, fish, etc., in large quantity

loans.name: Anonymous

He has 12 years of experience working as a farmer. He has been running his own farm since 2002. He works independently in his business. He cultivates different types of vegetables and fruits and delivers his products to local markets. Today, he is requesting to borrow $1,000 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase needed supplies for his agricultural work. He is willing to improve his business and hopes that the loan will help him increase his profits by 15%.

loans.use: to purchase supplies for his agricultural work

loans.name: Tamuyoneh Group

texts.en:
Salone Microfinance Trust (SMT), a partner of Kiva in Makeni, northern Sierra Leone, is very please to present to you members of the “Tamuyoneh” group. These are small scale entrepreneurs who have come to SMT/Kiva lenders to seek a loan of 2,400,000 Sierra Leonean leones for the entire group in order to invest in their respective businesses. 

Melrose K. is the leader of this group. Melrose was born in the southern city of Bo about 39 years ago. Melrose is married and has 4 children – 3 in primary school and 1 in secondary school. 

Melrose sells foo-foo (fast food made out of cassava roots), palm-oil and cassava. She has been running this business for 5 years now. With the help of this loan, she will expand her business by buying the above mentioned foodstuffs in larger quantities to add to her business.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en: Grace is currently in a business of maize flour. She is 30 years old, married, with 4 children and all of them go to school.Grace borrowed a loan to stock more maize flour to sell. Her future goal is to build a big shop with extra profits from her business.

loans.use: Stock more  maize flour to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous

For the past 30 years, he has  buil1 a good business reputation working as a home painter. He operates his business by taking private projects. Despite his old age, this man works tough to be able to pay his family expenses. Today, he is requesting to borrow $1200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l to purchase scaffolding and renew his tools. He is willing to take more painting projects in order to increase his profits. In the future, he is planning to expand his business operation.

loans.name: Na God De Gree Group

texts.en:

They are small-businesswomen who have come to SMT, a partner of Kiva in order to seek a loan of 800,000 Sierra Leonean leones for each member of the group. With this loan, they will be able to add more goods to their businesses, attract more customers, make more sales and profit, and consequently improve on their living conditions. 

The leader of this group of entrepreneurs is Aminata C.. Aminata was born in the town of Magburaka, in northern Sierra Leone, 47 years ago. She is married and has 4 children. Aminata has been selling cassava root, potatoes, palm oil, etc. for the past 10 years now. With her share of this loan, she will buy these things in bulk to add to her business.

loans.use: to buy cassava root, potatoes, palm oil, etc. in bulk

Therefore, she hopes to reduce the amount she spends on transportation by using her loan to purchase a used motorbike.

loans.name: Aidah

texts.en:
Aidah L. lives in the Nakulabye neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda.  She is single and has four children, three of whom are in school. She also takes care of additional family members.  Aidah has a business of selling charcoal.  She has been in this business for 6 years, and she works 7 days out of every week. Aidah sells her products at the market.    Aidah has requested a loan of 800,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bags of charcoal.    She also generates additional income through tailoring uniforms.

The main business challenges for Aidah include transportation and the rainy season.  Her goals and aspiration for her business are to own a delivery van and also to educate her children up to university.   Aidah lives in a home that she rents; she has access to electricity and to piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include school fees and rent

loans.use: to buy more bags of charcoal

loans.name: Anonymous

She is thankful for her decision to start her business, because with her income she was able to help her father with the family expenses. Today, she is requesting to borrow $1,000 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l to improve her business. She will purchase additional merchandise in order to better satisfy her customer’s demands.  She is very optimistic and has lots of future plans.

About HSPFI: HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional canned goods and snacks to sell

loans.name: Edina

texts.en: Edina G. is currently in a business selling food. She's 40 years old and married to a driver. They have seven children, all of them in school. Her goal is to build a better house.

loans.use: to buy stock for her cafe.

loans.name: Ufalme Group

texts.fr: Mbambu S.  est entrepreneur, leader du groupe d’affaire Ufalme, âgée de 43 ans, mariée, mère de 9 enfants parmi les quels, deux ont leurs propres foyers et sept vont à l’école.  Son conjoint est un fonctionnaire de l’Etat dans le service public. La  cliente  Mbambu S. est vendeuse des boissons locales communément appelées jus  Madrakwa. Il ya plusieurs années qu’elle exerce cette activité.  Elle vient de faire 8 cycles en bénéficiant régulièrement  le crédit de l’IMF  Hekima, pour  renforcer  son capital. La famille de la cliente Mbambu S. vit de cette activité d’autant plus que les fonctionnaires de L’Etat congolais ne sont pas régulièrement payés et quand ils sont payés, ils reçoivent de rémunération très médiocre qui ne leurs permet pas de couvrir l’ensemble de tout le mois ni de faire une épargne. Ce nouveau crédit doit lui servir de s’approvisionner  avec  des nouveaux intra (matières premières) pour la fabrication de ce jus mandrakwa (5 sacs maïs, 50 kg millet, 50 kg farine, 50 kg sorgho, bois de chauffage, etc.).  En plus, elle ambitionne pérenniser  son entreprise et scolariser dignement ses enfants. La cliente Mbambu S.  remercie l’IMF Hekima pour  ses actions dédiées aux pauvres femmes exclues de banque classique. Le groupe Ufalme est constitué de 20 membres majoritairement femmes. Cependant, l’une des clientes porte un bébé au dos.
texts.en: Mbambu S. is an entrepreneur and the leader of the Ufalme work group. She is 43 yeas old, married, and the mother of 9 children, two of whom already live separately and seven are still in school. Her husband is a governmental employee in public service. Mbambu S. sells traditional local drink called “madrakwa juice.” She has been in this business for several years. She just completed eight loan cycles with IMF Hekima, with the goal of bolstering her business capital. Mbambu S.’s family depends on her business, especially since public employees in Congo are not paid regularly, and when they do receive their salaries, the pay level is so low that it does not last the family for the entire month, nor does it allow for savings. This new loan will help Mbambu S. to stock up with the new ingredients (raw matters) in order to prepare “mandrakwa” (five bags of corn, 50 kg of millet, 50 kg of flour, 50 kg of sorghum, heating wood etc). In addition, her goal is to  ensure the continuation of her business and to provide for proper education for her children. As a client of IMF, Mbambu S. is grateful to IMF Hekima for its actions in support of impoverished women who do not have access to traditional banking. The Ufalme group is composed of 20 members, mainly women. One of the group members [in the photo] is carrying a child on her back.

loans.use: to purchase  bags of corn, 50 kg of millet, 50 kg of flour, 50 kg of sorghum, heating wood etc.

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Arlyn

texts.en:
Arlyn S. is from the village of Lurugan, Valencia City, Bukidnon. She is 29 years old and married with two school-aged children. To make a living, Arlyn owns a sari-sari (variety) shop selling products such as shampoo, soap, canned goods, snack foods, detergents and beverages. Arlyn has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 10000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Arlyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10000 PHP from HSPFI and is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the fourth loan taken out by Arlyn from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve/expand the her business. 

About HSPFI: HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional food products to sell

loans.name: Honest Labour Group

texts.en:
Meet with members of the “Honest Labour” group from Waterloo, a town in western Sierra Leone. They are all local entrepreneurs who have come to SMT, a partner of Kiva, to apply for a loan of SLL 800,000 for each. With the help of this loan they will be able to expand their businesses, make more sales and consequently improve on their living conditions. 

Aminata J. is the leader of this group. The 40 year-old is married and has 3 children, 2 of whom are attending secondary school. Aminata has been a businesswoman for more than 5 years now.  She sells milk, sardines, drinks, etc.  With her share of this loan, she will buy the above-mentioned items at wholesale to add to her business.

loans.use: to buy milk, sardines, drinks, etc., in large quantity

loans.name: Juliet

texts.en:
Juliet K. lives in the Nabulagala neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda.  She is divorced and has 4 children, three of whom are in school.  Juliet has a business of selling charcoal.  She has been in this business for 6 years, and she works 7 days out of every week.  Juliet sells her products at the market.   She has requested a loan of 700,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bags of charcoal. She also generates additional income through rental houses   .

The main business challenges for Juliet include transportation and thieves.  Her goals and aspirations for her business are to own a delivery van and also to invest in another business. Juliet lives in a home that she owns and has access to electricity and to piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include school fees, food and medication.

loans.use: to buy more bags of charcoal

loans.name: Badeya Kadi Group

texts.fr:
Les quatre membres du groupe BADEYA KADI sont des femmes mariées ayant une moyenne d’âge de 30  ans et ont en moyenne  2 enfants. Elles vivent la plupart dans des  familles monogames à Mancourani II un des quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles sont à leur premier prêt avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leurs clientèles.
DJENEBA T. fait le commerce de pomme de terre à travers ce groupe de femmes BADEYA KADI. 
Elle compte acheter avec son prêt 350kg de pomme de terre. Elle s’approvisionne dans les villages environnants Sikasso.
Elle les revend au grand marché de Sikasso, au marché du quartier Médine de Sikasso et en famille, à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes au comptant. 
 Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 31.500FCFA dont une partie est  utilisée  pour payer le prêt et son intérêt et l’autre pour son épargne.
Elle ambitionne d’augmenter son chiffre d’affaire pour mieux satisfaire sa clientèle.
texts.en:
The four members of the Badeya Kadi group are married women, averaging 30 years of age with two children. They live mainly in monogamous families in Mancourani II, a working-class district of the city of Sikasso, the third administrative district of Mali. 
They are on their first loan cycle with the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance institution, with the goal of better meeting customer demand.
As an example of this group’s business activities, Djeneba T. sells potatoes.

She plans to use her loan to purchase 350 kg [800 lbs] of potatoes. She stocks up in villages near Sikasso. She sells her goods at the big market of Sikasso, at the local market of the Médine district in Sikasso, and out of her home, for cash, to a customer base composed of both men and women. She plans to achieve an average monthly income of 31,500 West African francs, one part of which will be used to repay the loan and the interest on it, and the other part put away as savings. Her goal is to increase her business volume in order to better meet customer demand.

loans.use: to buy potatoes for resale

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Les quatre membres du groupe BENKADI sont des femmes mariées ayant une moyenne d’âge de 36  ans et ont en moyenne 3 enfants. Elles vivent la plupart dans des  familles polygames à Mancourani II un des quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles sont à leur premier prêt avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle.
ROKIA D. fait le commerce de  condiments alimentaires dans ce groupe de femmes BENKADI. 
Elle compte acheter avec son  prêt  2 paquets de condiments (légumes frais et séchés). Elle s’approvisionne à Sikasso ville et dans les villages environnants.
Elle les revend au marché de Mancourani dans la ville de Sikasso à une place fixe et en famille à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes au comptant. 
 Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 27.500FCFA dont une partie est  utilisée  pour payer le prêt et son intérêt et l’autre pour son épargne.
texts.en:
The four members of the BENKADI group are married women.  They are, on average, 36 years old and have three children.  They live mostly in polygamous families in Mancourani II, one of the popular districts of the city of Sikasso, the third administrative region of Mali. 
They are on their first loan with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso.  Their goal is to better satisfy the needs of their customers. 
In the BENKADI women’s group, Rokia D. sells food condiments.
With her loan, she plans to buy two packs of condiments (fresh and dried vegetables).  She gets her supplies in the city of Sikasso and in the neighboring villages.
She sells her condiments for cash at the Mancourani market in Sikasso, and within the family, to a clientele of men and women. 
She foresees earning an average monthly profit of 27,500 FCFA.  A part of this will be used to pay the loan and interest, and the rest will go into savings.

loans.use: to buy food condiments

loans.name: Dembagnouma. Group

texts.fr:
Dembagnouma est un regroupement de cinq femmes mariées  qui ont en moyenne 38  ans 3 enfants et vivant dans des  familles polygames à KABOILA II un des quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles sont à leur premier prêt avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle.
KADIA D. fait le commerce de fruits tels  les oranges dans ce groupe de femmes Dembagnouma de KABOILA. 
Elle compte acheter avec son  prêt  2 chargements de charrettes d’âne en orange. Elle s’approvisionne dans les vergers des villages environnants de Sikasso.
Elle les revend au  marché de Médine à Sikasso et en famille à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes au comptant. 
 Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 35.500FCFA dont une partie est  utilisée  pour payer le prêt et son intérêt et l’autre pour son épargne.
texts.en:
Dembagnouma is a group of five married women who average 38 years of age and average three children each.  They live in polygamous families in Kaboila II, a district of the city of Sikasso, in the third administrative region of Mali.
They are on their first loan with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso. Their goal is to better satisfy the needs of their customers.
In the women’s group Dembagnouma, Kadia D. sells fruits such as oranges. 
With her loan, she plans to buy two wagon loads of oranges.  She gets her supplies from the orchards in the villages surrounding Sikasso.  
She sells her fruit, for cash, at the Médine market in Sikasso and within the family to a clientele of men and women. 
She foresees earning an average monthly profit of 35,500 FCFA.  A part of this will be used to pay the loan and interest, and the rest will go into savings.

loans.use: to buy oranges

loans.name: Gnogondeme Group

texts.fr:
Les dix  membres du groupe GNOGONDEME sont des femmes mariées  qui ont une moyenne d’âge de 40  ans, et ont en moyenne  4 enfants. Elles vivent la plupart dans des  familles polygames à Siékourani un des villages de la commune de Loulouni, préfecture de Kadiolo (Sikasso) 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles sont à leur quatrième prêt avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle et tous les trois prêts précédents  se sont bien dénoués.
MARIAM O. fait l’achat vente de riz dans ce groupe de femmes GNOGONDEME. 
Elle compte acheter avec son  prêt  200kg de grains de riz. Elle s’approvisionne à Siékourani et dans les villages environnants.
Elle les revend au  marché du village et de la ville de Loulouni, à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes au comptant. 
 Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 22.500FCFA dont une partie est  utilisée  pour payer le prêt et son intérêt et l’autre pour son épargne.
Elle ambitionne d’augmenter son chiffre d’affaire pour mieux satisfaire sa clientèle.
texts.en:
The ten members of the GNOGONDEME group are married women.  They are, on average,  40 years old and have four children.  They live mostly in polygamous families in Siékourani, one of the villages of the Loulouni commune, in the Kadiolo (Sikasso) prefecture, the third administrative region of Mali. 
They are on their fourth loan with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso, with the goal of being able to meet the needs of their customers.  The previous three loans have all been properly repaid.
Mariam O., one of the women in the GNOGONDEME group, buys and sells rice.
She plans to buy 200 kg of rice with her loan.  She gets her supplies in Siékourani and in the neighboring villages.
She sells the rice for cash at the village market in the city of Loulouni to a clientele of men and women.
She foresees earning an average monthly benefit of 22,500 FCFA.  A part of this will be used to pay the loan and interest, and the rest will go into savings.
She aspires to increase her turnover to be better able meet the needs of her clients.

loans.use: to buy rice

loans.name: Kalomp Group

texts.en:
In the photo are members of the “Kalomp” group. They are small scale businessmen based in Waterloo, a small town near Freetown. They have requested a loan of SLL 3,500,000 from SMT/Kiva lenders in order to expand their businesses. 

The leader of this group is Mohamed K.. Mohamed is age 38. He was born in the village of Masiaka, in northern Sierra Leone. Currently, he is residing in Waterloo, together with his wife and 3 children. His wife is a businesswoman and two of his children attend secondary school.  The other one is not of school age. 

Mohamed sells clothes, trousers, shoes, belts, bags, etc. He has been doing this type of business for 2 years now. With the help of this loan, he will buy the above mentioned items in large quantity to add to his business.

loans.use: To buy clothes, trousers, shoes, belts, bags, etc, in large quantity

loans.name: Jiguiseme Group

texts.fr:
Les  membres du groupe JIGUISEME sont des femmes mariées ayant une moyenne d’âge de 32  ans, et ont en moyenne  3 enfants. Elles vivent la plupart dans des  familles polygames à SIEKOURANI un des villages de la commune de Loulouni préfecture de Kadiolo (Sikasso) 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles sont à leur deuxième collaboration  avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle. Le prêt précédent s’est bien dénoué.
FATOU T., du groupe JIGUISEME fait le commerce de condiments. 
Elle compte acheter avec son  prêt  2 paniers de choux, 100kg d’oignons, 2 paniers de tomates,  1 petit carton de cube maggi, 10kg de sel de cuisine et 1paquet d’autres produits. Elle s’approvisionne au marché de la ville de Loulouni les jours de foires. Elle les revend au  marché du village et en famille à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes au comptant. 
 Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 12.750FCFA dont une partie est  utilisée  pour payer le prêt et son intérêt et l’autre pour son épargne.
Elle ambitionne d’augmenter son chiffre d’affaire pour mieux satisfaire sa clientèle.
texts.en:
The members of the group JIGUISEME are married women averaging 32 years of age and three children on average. The women live for the most part in polygamous families in SIEKOURANI, a village in the commune of Loulouni, prefecture of Kadiolo (Sikasso), in the 3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali. The group members are on their second collaboration with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso in order to satisfy the needs of their customers. The previous loan has been settled.

Ms. FATOU T., belonging to the group JIGUISEME, does commerce in condiments. She plans on using her loan to buy: 2 baskets of cabbage, 100 kg of onions, 2 baskets of tomatoes, 1 small box of Maggi bouillon cubes, 10 kg of table salt, and 1 pack of other goods. She gets her supplies at the market in Loulouni City on market days. She sells the goods for cash at the village market and at the house. Her customer base is composed of women and men.

She envisions making an average monthly profit of 12,750 francs CFA. A portion of the profits will be used for paying the loan interest, and the other portion will be put into savings. Her ambition is to increase her turnover, so as to satisfy her customers further.

loans.use: To buy condiments

loans.name: Aleksan

texts.en:
Aleksan A. was born in 1949 in Ijevan. He has two daughters and a son.  Aleksan’s children are married and live separately from their parents. 
For about 15 years, Aleksan Antnonyan worked as a driver.  Now he and his wife are engaged animal husbandry.  With the profits from farming, Aleksan provides for his family’s needs, such as buying necessary furniture and organizing his children’s weddings. He also helped his son to set up his own business. 
This is Aleksan’s third loan from Nor Horizon and second loan from Kiva. He has never delayed his loan repayments, and now he is asking for a 600,000 AMD loan to buy one more cow, and fodder for his farm animals.

loans.use: to buy one more cow, and fodder for his farm animals

loans.name: Sabali Kagni Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe SABALI KAGNI est constitué de femmes mariées ayant une moyenne d’âge de 32  ans et ont en moyenne  2 enfants. Elles vivent la plupart dans des  familles polygamiques à SIEKOURANI un des villages de la commune de Loulouni préfecture de Kadiolo (Sikasso) 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles sont à leur quatrième prêt avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle et tous les trois prêts précédents se sont bien dénoués.
ADAM S. fait le commerce d’articles de boutique dans ce groupe de femmes SABALI KAGNI. 
Elle compte acheter avec son  prêt,  10 cartouches de cigarettes, 50,kg de sucre, 1 carton de lait concentré,  2 cartons de thé,  1 bidon de 10 litres d’huile végétale, 1 paquet d’autres articles. Elle s’approvisionne au grand marché de Sikasso. Elle  revend dans sa boutique à Siékourani village, en face du goudron (la Route.Nationale) qui va jusqu’à ZEGOUA, à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes, au comptant. 
 Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 37.500FCFA dont une partie est  utilisée  pour payer le prêt et son intérêt et l’autre pour son épargne.
texts.en: The SABALI KAGNI group is composed of married women who are, on average, 32 years old with 2 children.   Most of them live in polygamous families in SIEKOURANI, one of the villages of the Loulouni commune, prefecture of Kadiolo (Sikasso), third administrative region of Mali.  This is their fourth loan with the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance institution. They are requesting the loan to satisfy the needs of their customers; all three previous loans have been fully repaid.  In this group of Sabali Kagni women, ADAM S. sells shop items.  With her loan, she plans to buy 10 cartons of cigarettes, 50 kg of sugar, 1 carton of condensed milk, 2 cartons of tea, 1 drum of vegetable oil, and one packet of other items.  She gets her supplies at the Sikasso Grand Market and sells them to a clientele composed of men and women for cash in her shop in Siékourani village, in front of the goudron [a tarmac road, the National Route] that goes to Zegoua.  She hopes to make an average monthly profit of 37,500 CFA, part of which will be used to pay down the principal and interest of her loan and the remainder for her savings.

loans.use: To buy items to sell in a shop

loans.name: Agnes Mutete

texts.en:
Agnes K., aged 33 years, is married to Daniel K. and together they have two children – Benson (aged 15 years, in form three) and Cecilia Wanjiku (aged 13 years, in form one). The family lives in Uhuru Estate.
Agnes' primary business is selling second-hand women's clothes in Nairobi town center. She was introduced to Kiva partner, KADET, by KADET staff. Agnes has been operating her business for four years and generates a monthly profit of 20,000 KES. This loan of 40,000 KES is her first loan from KADET and she plans to use it to add new stock of blouses and skirts. If the loan boosts her business she hopes to open another business. She dreams of having many shops in the future. Agnes describes herself as hardworking.

loans.use: to add new stock of blouses and skirts

loans.name: Yerekun Gnini. Group

texts.fr:
Les neuf membres du groupe YEREKUN GNINI sont des femmes mariées, avec une moyenne d’âge de 33  ans, et ont en moyenne  2 enfants. Elles vivent la plupart dans des  familles polygames à SIEKOURANI un des villages de la commune de Loulouni préfecture de Kadiolo (Sikasso) 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles sont à leur premier prêt avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle.
SITAN K. fait le commerce d’ignames dans ce groupe de femmes YEREKUN GNINI. 
Elle compte acheter avec son  prêt,  600kg d’ignames. Elle s’approvisionne à Siékourani et dans les villages environnants.  Elle revend au  marché de Siékourani et au marché de Loulouni ville les jours de foires à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes au comptant. 
 Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 14.750FCFA dont une partie est  utilisée  pour payer le prêt et son intérêt et l’autre pour son épargne.
texts.en:
The nine members of the YEREKUN GNINI group are married women who average 33 years of age and two children each. Most of them live in polygamous families in SIEKOURANI, a village in the commune of Loulouni, prefecture of Kadiolo, in Sikasso (third administrative region of Mali).

This is their first loan with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso to satisfy their customers’ needs.

Sitan K. is a member of the YEREKUN GNINI group. She sells yams. She plans to use her loan to buy 600 kg of yams. She gets her stock in Siékourani and surrounding villages. She conducts her sales at the markets of Siékourani and Loulouni, for cash, to a clientele composed of both men and women.

She expects to earn an average monthly profit of 14,750 FCFA, which she will use to repay the loan and interest, and to bolster her savings.

loans.use: to buy yams for resale

loans.name: Bamory

texts.fr:
Monsieur BAMORY S. est né le 23 octobre 1966 à BAMAKO. Père de 3 enfants, il vit dans une famille nucléaire à Noumousso - Kadiolo (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Il mène des activités de commercialisation de produits agricoles et alimentaires depuis maintenant 15 ans. Son expérience dans ce domaine, lui a valu une bonne réputation et reçoit des commandes de produits et cela en permanence. Ainsi pour avoir les ressources nécessaires afin de satisfaire ses clients, il décida de collaborer avec l’Institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso. Après avoir correctement remboursé le premier prêt il est à son deuxième prêt de groupe.  
Ce prêt lui permettra d’acheter de l’igname : 800kg et des bananes plantains:50régimes. Il s’approvisionne en Côte d’Ivoire, un pays frontalier du MALI. Les produits sont directement acheminés à MOPTI pour être livrés. Il  sont vendus au comptant à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Avec ce prêt, il envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 100 000 FCFA. Ce bénéfice lui permettra de payer  son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
 Il compte devenir un grossiste de bonne renommée à fin de satisfaire ses nombreux clients qui ne cessent de croître.
texts.en:
Mr. Bamory S. was born on October 23 1966 in Bamako.   Father of three children, he lives with his nuclear family in Noumousso – Kadiolo (the third largest administrative region in the republic of Mali).  

For the past 15 years he has marketed agricultural and food products.  His experience in this industry has earned him a good reputation and he constantly receives product orders.  In order to have the resources necessary to satisfy his customers, he decided to collaborate with Soro Yiriwaso, a microfinance institution.  After properly repaying his first loan, he is at his second loan from the group.  

This loan will allow him to buy 800 kg of yams and 50 bunches of plantains.  He stocks up in the Ivory Coast, a country bordering Mali.  The products are transported directly to MOPTI for delivery.  They are sold for cash to a clientele composed of men and women.

With this loan, he expects to make an average monthly profit of 100,000 FCFA. This profit will enable him to repay his loan and invest the rest in his business.  He plans to become a reputable wholesaler in order to satisfy his many customers who continue to grow more numerous.

loans.use: to buy food products

loans.name: Lassine

texts.fr:
Monsieur Lassine Koné est né le 05 mars 1975 à BAMAKO. Père d’un enfant et époux d’une femme, il vit dans une famille traditionnelle à Noumousso - Kadiolo (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
 Il excelle dans l’achat vente de céréales depuis 12 ans. Son expérience dans ce domaine, lui a valu une bonne réputation. Lassine reçoit des commandes de céréales, notamment du maïs. Ainsi pour avoir les ressources nécessaires afin de satisfaire sa clientèle, il  continu de collaborer avec l’Institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso. Il est à son quatrième prêt de groupe après avoir correctement remboursés les trois précédents.  
Ce prêt lui permettra d’acheter 4 tonnes de maïs et 1 tonne de mil. Il s’approvisionne dans les villages avoisinants Kadiolo. Les céréales sont d’abord stockées dans son magasin. Il  les revend au comptant à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes venant de Sikasso et de Bamako. 
Avec ce prêt, il envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 150 000 FCFA. Ce bénéfice lui permettra de payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Mr. Lassine Koné was born on March 5, 1975 in Bamako. Father of one child and husband of one wife, he lives in a traditional family in Noumousso – Kadiolo (the third largest administrative region in the republic of Mali).

He has been excelling at the purchase and sale of cereals for the past 12 years.  His experience in this sector has earned him a good reputation.  Lassine receives cereal orders, including corn. In order to have the resources necessary to satisfy his customers, he continues to work with Siri Yiriwaso, a microfinance organization.  He is on his fourth loan from the group after having completely repaid his previous three loans.

This loan will enable him to buy 4 tons of corn and 1 ton of millet. He stocks up in the neighboring villages of Kadiolo.  The grains are first stored in his store. He resells them for cash to a clientele composed of men and women from Sikasso and from Bamako.

With this loan, he expects to earn an average monthly profit of 150,000 FCFA. This profit will allow him to repay the interest on his loan and invest the rest in his business.

loans.use: to buy cereals

loans.name: Hold Am Fine Group

texts.en:
Meet with members of the “Hold Am Fine” group from Waterloo, a small town in western Sierra Leone. They are all local entrepreneurs who have come to SMT, a partner of Kiva.org, to apply for a loan of SLL 500,000 for each. With the help of this loan they will be able to expand their businesses, make more sales and consequently improve on their living conditions. 

Abu Bakarr K. is the leader of this group. The 34-year-old is married to a businesswoman.  They have 2 children who are not of school age. Abu Bakarr has been a businessman for 5 years now.  He sells groundnuts. With his share of this loan, he will buy groundnuts in large quantity to add to his business.

loans.use: to buy groundnuts in large quantity

loans.name: Maureen

texts.en:
Maureen A. lives in the Naguru neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda.  She is married and has 5 children, all of whom are in school. She also takes care of additional family members.  Maureen has a business of selling charcoal.  She has been in this business for 6 years, and she works 7 days out of every week. Maureen sells her products at the market.    Maureen has requested a loan of 500,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more baskets of tomatoes, cabbage and onions   She also generates additional income through a motorcycle for hire    .

The main business challenges for Maureen include transportation and seasonality.  Her goals and aspirations for her business are to own a delivery van and also to buy her own land.   Maureen lives in a home that she owns. She has access to electricity and to piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include school fees, food and medication.

loans.use: to buy more baskets of tomatoes, onions and cabbages

loans.name: Joseph Muchiri

texts.en:
Joseph Muchiri is 45 years old, married to Martha Njeri who is a housewife, and has three children – Antony, Brian, and Antony Mwangi. He lives in Kingstone with his family. His primary business is farming and he has been in this business for five years.
Joseph's business is located in the Kingstone area where he sells milk to Daima Company located in the same area. He was introduced to Kiva partner, KADET, by the credit officer in charge of Eastlands office. Joseph’s business gives him a monthly profit of 10,000 KES. This loan of 50,000 KES is his first loan with KADET and he plans to use it to buy food for his cattle and pigs. If the loan boosts his business, he plans to add another dairy cow. Joseph’s hope and dream is to become one of the best farmers in the country. He describes himself as hardworking.

loans.use: to buy food for cattle and pigs

loans.name: Enkaiser

texts.en:
Enkaiser E. K., a 40-year-old married mother of five children, has been farming her own piece of land for the past two years. Enkaiser, who was first introduced to KADET LTD by a KADET staff member in her town, is requesting her third loan to buy wheat seed and fertilizer. She hopes to use the additional profits arising from this loan both to expand her farming activity from small-scale to large-scale and to buy a few cows for fattening.

A thorough woman determined to achieve her goals, Enkaiser dreams of being able to provide a high level of education to her children.

loans.use: to buy wheat seed and fertilizer.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy a motorbike

loans.name: Zenah

texts.en:
Zenah is 55 years old and has been in mixed farming for over five years. She is married, with six children.  They are all adults except one, aged sixteen. Zenah's maize, eggs, milk and beans are sold in the local market. She earns additional income from her teaching employment.
