Carla's business is selling all types of clothes.  She makes her sales door to door and also sells from her parents' home to customers who come to her.  She works every day from 9.00am to 3.00pm, leaves her goods on credit and collects payment every week.  She buys her merchandise in Guayaquil every fortnight or every month, depending on what she needs.  She tells us that she has been in this business for three years and it is doing very well.

Carla will use this loan to buy pants, t-shirts, blouses, children's clothes, underwear and other clothes.  Her dream is to grow her business.

loans.use: to buy pants, t-shirts, blouses, children's clothes, underwear, etc.

loans.name: Alimatu

texts.en:
This is 50 year-old Alimatu S..  She is a widow, and has one child who is a driver. In 1991, Alimatu S. established her clothing business. She began her business because she never attended school and needed to get a means of livelihood for her family. 

Working 6 days a week and 10 hours a day, she earns about 800,000 Sierra Leonean leones (SLL) every month from this business. She would like a loan in the amount of 3,000,000 SLL. Alimatu requires a loan in order to buy more stock of her clothing for sale. She has the intention of using the proceeds from this loan to build a house. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to buy clothing for resale

loans.name: Ertrudes

texts.es:
En el cantón 24 De Mayo de la  provincia de Manabí, se reúne cada quince días el Banco Comunal Madre Para Un Futuro Mejor. Este cantón es conocido por sus paisajes hermosos, por sus bosques, por la variedad de su fauna y por su gente amable y  trabajadora que en su mayoría se  dedican a la agricultura y ganadería.

En este lugar encontramos a la señora Ertrudes. Ella tiene 55 años de edad, está casada y fruto de relación tiene un hijo de 17 años, el cual este año empieza a estudiar en Universidad. Su esposo es comerciante.

Ella se dedica al comercio, tiene un pequeño bar en donde vende bebidas como: gaseosas, aguas, cervezas, bebidas energizantes y batidos de frutas. También prepara y vende empanadas, hamburguesas, entre otros bocadillos. Trabaja todos los días desde las 8h00 hasta las 19h00, nos cuenta que lleva como 15 años dedicada a su negocio y que le va muy bien y además se entretiene  en el.

Este crédito lo va a utilizar para comprar: gaseosas, bebidas energizantes, aguas, cervezas, pan e ingredientes para los alimentos entre  otros productos. Es socia del Banco Comunal desde el inicio y le gusta por la ayuda que recibe con los créditos. Su sueño es tener buena salud.
texts.en:
The Communal Bank “Madre Para Un Futuro Mejor” (Mother for a Better Future) meets every fifteen days in the May 24th Canton in Manabí Province. This canton is known for its beautiful landscapes, its forests, and the variety of plant life. The people are friendly and hardworking. Most of them engage in agriculture and livestock breeding.

It is in this place that one can find Sra. Ertrudes. She is 55 years old, married, and has a 17 year old son who is in his first year of study at the university. Her husband is a merchant.

Ertrudes is a businesswoman. She has a small bar where she sells beverages such as sodas, water, beer, energy drinks, and fruit smoothies. In addition, she prepares and sells turnovers, hamburgers, and other snacks. She works every day from 8am to 7pm. Ertrudes says that she has been in business for fifteen years and has done very well because her work keeps her busy.

This loan will be used to buy sodas, energy drinks, water, beer, bread, ingredients for preparing food, and other products. She has been a member of the Communal Bank since the beginning and enjoys the assistance she has received through the loans. Her dream is to have good health.

loans.use: To purchase sodas, energy drinks, water, beer, bread, ingredients for preparing food, and other products.

loans.name: Dolores María

texts.es:
En el cantón 24 De Mayo de la  provincia de Manabí se reúne cada quince días el Banco Comunal Madre Para Un Futuro Mejor. Este cantón es conocido por sus paisajes hermosos, por sus bosques, por la variedad de su fauna y por su gente amable y  trabajadora que en su mayoría se dedica a la agricultura y ganadería.
 
La señora Dolores es socia fundadora del Banco comunal hace más de 15 años,  le gusta porque siempre le han ayudado con los créditos. Tiene 56 años de edad, está casada y de esta relación tuvo cuatro hijos y uno falleció, todos son  mayores de edad pero dos de ellos que son casados  aun viven con ella, tiene dos nietos y uno que esta  por venir. Su esposo es  comerciante.

Se dedica al comercio, vende sabanas, toldos y semijoyas. Su forma de venta es puerta a puerta y también vende en su casa, nos dice que la mayoría de sus ventas son bajo  pedido. Trabaja todos los días, sus productos los deja a crédito y cobra cada ocho días. Su mercadería  la compra en  Guayaquil cada quince días o al mes de acuerdo a lo que necesite. Nos cuenta que lleva diez años que se dedica a esta actividad y que le va muy bien.

Este crédito es para comprar sabanas, toldos y semijoyas ya que tiene algunos pedidos. Su sueño es crecer con su negocio.
texts.en:
The Communal Bank “Madre Para Un Futuro Mejor” (Mother for a Better Future) meets every fifteen days in the May 24th Canton in the Manabí Province. This canton is known for its beautiful landscapes, its forests, and the variety of plant life. The people are friendly and hardworking. Most of them engage in agriculture and livestock breeding.

Sra. Dolores became a founding member of the Communal Bank more than fifteen years ago. She has always enjoyed the assistance she receives through the loans. Dolores is 56 years old, married, and has four children, but one of them is deceased. All of her surviving children are grown, but two of them are married and still live with her. Dolores has two grandchildren and another one on the way. Her husband is a merchant.

She has a business selling bedding, tarps, and costume jewelry. Dolores sells door-to-door and also from her home. She says that most of her sales are made through orders. Dolores works every day, offering her products on credit and collecting payment every eight days. Her merchandise is purchased in Guayaquil every fifteen days or on a monthly basis based on what is needed. She indicates that she has been in business for ten years and has done very well.

This loan will be used to buy bedding, tarps, and costume jewelry since she has a few outstanding orders. Her dream is to grow with her business.

loans.use: To purchase bedding, tarps, and costume jewelry.

loans.name: Kadiatu

texts.en:
This is 56 year-old Kadiatu.  She is a widow and has 3 children ages 34, 29, and 29. She has six additional dependents, who live with her because they are orphans.

In 1987, Kadiatu established her cookery (cooked food) business. She began her business because she learnt the business from her parents: "Since I was not sent to school I preferred selling for my survival." 

Working 7 days a week and 12 hours a day, she earns about 100,000 Sierra Leonean leones (SLL) every month from this business. She would like a loan in the amount of 3,000,000 SLL. Kadiatu requires a loan in order to buy more foodstuffs. She hopes that this loan will enable her to increase her monthly profits by approximately 300,000 SLL. In the future, Kadiatu plans to educate her children to university level.   She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to buy more food for her business

loans.name: Mariama  K

texts.en: This is 34 year-old Mariama.  She is married and has four children. In 2005, Mariama established her grocery. She began her business because she wants to fight poverty and to help her husband in providing a livelihood for the family. Mariama opens her business every day except on Sundays. Mariama has a good loan repayment history. She needs a loan of 4,000,000 Sierra Leonean leones (SLL). Mariama requires a loan in order to buy more foodstuffs. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to buy grocery store inventory

loans.name: Rosario Esther

texts.es: Solicitante, tiene 38 años, es madre soltera, vive en casa familiar,  se dedica al transporte,  cuenta con una moto taxi que es alquilada. Tiene la meta de tener otra unidad de transporte, y tener negocio propio cumpliendo  sus sueños y objetivos  asi solucionando sus problemas se propone el credito por ser una persona emprendedora , solicita credito para gastos personales y mejoras para su vehiculo
texts.en:
Rosario, age 38, is a single mother who lives in the family home. She engages in the transportation sector and has a motorcycle taxi that she makes available for rent. Her goal is to obtain another vehicle. Having her own business has enabled her to fulfill her dreams and goals, as well as solve her problems.

Rosario is being recommended for this loan because she is an enterprising person. The loan she is requesting will be used for personal expenses and upgrades to her vehicle.

loans.use: To pay for upgrades to her motorcycle taxi and cover some personal expenses.

loans.name: Yuri Jofre

texts.es:
Yuri de 42 años, es un hombre trabajador que tiene muchas aspiraciones de seguir ganando dinero por su familia. Desde muy joven él comenzó a trabajar como taxista. 

En la actualidad el trabaja desde muy temprano haciendo carreras a diferentes lugares de Guayaquil. La tarifa que la cobra para las carreras es según sea el kilometraje que gaste es un promedio de $ 1.00 hasta $ 10.00. Tiene muchas aspiraciones con su taxi por eso quiere seguir trabajando, por ahora quiere compran con el préstamo llantas, tijeras, y herramientas para su taxi.
texts.en:
Yuri, age 42, is a hardworking gentleman who has many aspirations to continue earning money for his family. He started working as a taxi driver at a very young age.

Yuri currently starts his work very early, making the routes through different areas of Guayaquil. The fare he charges is based on the number of kilometers traveled, with the average fare ranging from $1.00 to $10.00. He has many plans for his taxi because he wants to continue working. Yuri will now use this loan to buy tires, a scissor jack, and tools for his taxi.

loans.use: To purchase tires, a scissor jack, and tools for his taxi.

loans.name: Patricia Evangelina

texts.es:
En el cantón 24 De Mayo de la  provincia de Manabí se reúne cada quince días el Banco Comunal Madre Para Un Futuro Mejor. Este cantón es conocido por sus paisajes hermosos, por sus bosques, por la variedad de su fauna y por su gente amable y  trabajadora que en su mayoría se dedica a la agricultura y ganadería.
 
En este lugar conocimos a la señora Patricia, ella tiene  50 años de edad, está casada y de esta relación tiene tres hijos, uno ya es mayor de edad, una jovencita que estudia en colegio y el menor que tiene 13 años es discapacitado. Su esposo es chofer.

Tiene un salón de belleza en el cual  realiza tinturados, cortes de cabellos, manicura de uñas y otros trabajos. Trabaja desde las 8am hasta las 20h00 y a veces hasta más tarde si sus clientes requieren de sus servicios. En su negocio tiene dos vitrinas en las que tiene ropa y productos Sayson y Lebel (productos de belleza, cosméticos, perfumería y accesorios para damas),  vende sus productos al mismo  tiempo cuando realiza sus otros trabajos.

Este crédito lo va a emplear en comprar tintes, permanentes, ropa de todo tipo y productos de Lebel y Sayson.  Está en el Banco Comunal  hace tres años y le gusta todo del banco, además se distrae  en las reuniones. Su sueño es tener un carro.
texts.en:
The Communal Bank “Madre Para Un Futuro Mejor” (Mother for a Better Future) meets every fifteen days in the May 24th Canton in the Manabí Province. This canton is known for its beautiful landscapes, its forests, and the variety of plant life. The people are friendly and hardworking. Most of them engage in agriculture and livestock breeding.

It is in this place that one can find Sra. Patricia. She is 50 years old, married, and has three children. One child is an adult, another is a high school student, and the youngest is 13 years old and disabled. Her husband works as a chaffeur.

Patricia has a beauty salon where she offers hair coloring, haircuts, manicures, and other services. She works from 8am to 8pm, and sometimes much later if her customers are in need of her services. In her business, she also has two display cabinets where she keeps clothing and products made by Sayson and Lebel (brands of beauty products, cosmetics, perfumes, and women’s accessories). She sells these products in addition to the other services she provides.

This loan will be used to buy dyes, perms, clothing of all types, and products manufactured by Lebel and Sayson. Patricia has been with the Communal Bank for three years and enjoys everything about it. In addition, the meetings provide a distraction. Her dream is to own a car.

loans.use: To purchase hair dyes, perms, clothing, and beauty products.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more plastic utensils for her business

loans.name: Foray

texts.en: This is 28 year-old S..  He is single, and has no children.   In 2008, S. established his drinks and top up (phone card) business. Working 7 days a week and 10 hours a day, he earns about Le 900,000 every month from this business. He would like a loan in the amount of Le 3,000,000. S. requires a loan in order to buy additional beer, stout, Heineken and soft drinks. He hopes that this loan will enable him to increase his monthly profits by approximately Le 300,000. In the future, S. plans to own a building and get married.   He thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to buy drinks for resale

loans.name: Adelsa

texts.en:
Adelsa P. is from the village of Palayan, Aloran, Misamis Occidental. She is 26 years old. Adelsa is married and has 2 very young children. To make a living, Adelsa owns & operates a specialized retail store selling products for daily use, such as shampoo, soap and toothpaste. Adelsa has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 10000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Adelsa joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Adelsa has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20000 PHP from GDMPC.  She is requesting a new loan of 30000 PHP, which will be used to purchase rice and corn grits, bagoong and dried fish for sale. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Adelsa from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has seven branches  covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase rice and corn grits, bagoong and dried fish for sale.

loans.name: Luis Arturo

texts.es: El solicitante Luis Arturo R. Calderón de dedica a la actividad de decoración en eventos para fiestas infantiles matrimonios entre otros eligió esta actividad por que le generaba buenos ingresos es soltero vive en casa familiar ayuda a sus padres en los gastos familiares tiene buenas referencias personales y laborales su sueño a futuro es hacer crecer mas su negocio y hacerse mas reconocido , esta solicitando el crédito para comprar materiales para su pequeña empresa como telas toldos maquetas entre otros es por ello que se propone el crédito
texts.en:
Luis Arturo R. Calderón has a business providing decorations for events such as children’s parties, weddings, and other occasions. He chose this business because it generates good income. Luis is single and lives in the family home. He helps his parents with the family expenses.

Luis has good personal and work-related references. His dream for the future is to grow his business even more and become well-recognized. He is requesting this loan to buy materials for his small business such as fabrics, tarps, mannequins, and other items. Therefore, he is being recommended for this loan.

loans.use: To purchase materials for his small business such as fabrics, tarps, mannequins, and other items.

loans.name: Hawa

texts.en: This is 34 year-old Hawa.  She is married and has 3 children, aged 18, 16 and 13.  In 2001, Hawa established her provision shop business. Hawa got her first stock on credit from a friend and later accumulated a profit, which she used to open a provision shop. She began her business with the hope of generating enough income to help her husband support their family. Working 7 days a week and 11 hours a day, she earns about 100,000 from her business every month. Hawa needs a loan of Le 3,000,000 in order to buy milk, sugar, tea, sardines, margarine, etc., for her shop. She hopes that this loan will enable her to increase her monthly profits by approximately Le 300,000. In the future, Hawa plans to get a house for her family.   She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to buy milk, sugar, tea, sardines, margarine, etc., for her shop.

loans.name: Lucia

texts.es:
En el cantón 24 De Mayo de la  provincia de Manabí se reúne cada quince días el Banco Comunal Madre Para Un Futuro Mejor. Este cantón es conocido por sus paisajes hermosos, por sus bosques, por la variedad de su fauna y por su gente amable y  trabajadora que en su mayoría se dedica a la agricultura y ganadería.

Aquí conocimos a la señora Lucia, ella tiene 47 de edad, es madre soltera de dos hijos de 14 y 8 años de edad que estudian en colegio y escuela. Ella tiene su casa propia en la que vive con sus hijos.

Trabaja de empleada pública en el cuerpo de bomberos 24 de mayo y además se desenvuelve como comerciante, vende ropa, principalmente ropa interior, sobrecamas y toallas. Su forma de  venta es puerta a puerta y a esto le ayudan su hija y sus hermanas. Trabaja cuatro  días por las noches y los fines de semana todo el día,  sus productos los deja a crédito y cobra cada ocho días. Su mercadería compra en  Guayaquil. Nos cuenta que lleva diez años que se dedica a esta actividad y que le va muy bien.

Este crédito es para comprar sabanas y ropa interior para estudiantes que están por iniciar las clases. Está en el Banco Comunal de diez años y le gusta por la ayuda y por la forma de trabajar de la institución. Sus sueños son tener un gran local y ser empresaria.
texts.en:
The Communal Bank “Madre Para Un Futuro Mejor” (Mother for a Better Future) meets every fifteen days in the May 24th Canton in the Manabí Province. This canton is known for its beautiful landscapes, its forests, and the variety of plant life. The people are friendly and hardworking. Most of them engage in agriculture and livestock breeding.

It is in this place that one can meet Sra. Lucia. She is 47 years old and a single mother of two children (ages 14 and 8) who are high school and elementary school students respectively. Lucia has her own home where she lives with her children.

Lucia is a public employee who works at the May 24th Fire Station and also has a retail business. She sells clothing (primarily undergarments), bedspreads, and towels. Lucia sells door-to-door and also has the help of her daughter and her sisters. She works in the evenings four days per week and all day on the weekends. Lucia offers her products on credit and collects payments every eight days. Her merchandise is acquired in Guayaquil. She says that she has been in business for ten years and has done very well.

This loan will be used to buy bedding and children’s undergarments since students are starting their classes. Lucia has been with the Communal Bank for ten years and enjoys the assistance and the organization’s method of working. Her dreams are to have a large store and become a businesswoman.

loans.use: To purchase undergarments and bed sheets.

loans.name: Juanito

texts.en:
Juanito S. is from the village of Sta. Ana Aloran, Mis. Occ.. He is 35 years old. Juanito is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Juanito owns & operates a business providing transportation services to the local community. Juanito has been engaged in his business for over 8 years and earns approximately 1000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2011, Juanito joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Juanito is requesting a loan of 25,000 PHP, which will be used to repair a transport vehicle for better services. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Juanito from GDMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has seven branches covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to repair a transport vehicle for better services

loans.name: Arlyn

texts.en:
Arlyn M. is from the village of Tipan, Oroquieta City. She is 20 years old. Arlyn is married and has one school-age child. To make a living, Arlyn owns and operates a service-based business. The main source of income for the business comes from providing transportation services to the local community. Arlyn has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month for these activities. In 2010, Arlyn joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Arlyn has successfully repaid a previous loan from GDMPC. Arlyn is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase motor accessories and a raincoat for better services. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Arlyn from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. About GDMPC:
GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has seven branches covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase motor accessories and a raincoat for better services.

loans.name: Ramatu

texts.en: This is 33-year-old Ramatu. She is married and has one child, age 12. She has five additional dependents. In 2009, Ramatu established her cooked-food (cookery) business. She began her business so that she can help her husband cover some of the household expenses. She opens her business six days a week and nine hours a day. She would like a loan in the amount of 3,000,000 SLL. Ramatu requires a loan in order to buy more foodstuff for her cookery business. In the future, Ramatu plans to help her son through his education. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to buy more foodstuff for her business

loans.name: Elvia Betsabeth

texts.es: Elvia, tiene 30 años es madre soltera, vive en casa de sus padres, ella actualmente se dedica a brindar el servicio de alquiler de autos para taxi , sus principales clientes son vecinos de su zona, ella los atiende con gran  amabilidad y calidez, esta actividad la desempeña por  mas de 3 años, negocio que le ha permitido obtener mayores ingresos que le sirven para los gastos de la casa, ya que tiene que afrontar sola la manutención de su menor hijo, quien aún esta en edad escolar, adicional a este negocio también se dedica a la venta de ropa en su domicilio, negocio que le permite generar ingresos, el sueño de Elvia es poder hacer crecer su negocio e implementarlo con venta de otros accesorios que le permiten trabajar desde la comodidad de su domicilio, ella desea invertir en la compra de ropa la cual podra ofrecer a sus clientes y de esta manera obtener mayores ingresos.
texts.en:
Elvia, age 30, is a single mother who lives in the home of her parents.  She currently has a service renting out automobiles to use as taxis.  Her main customers are neighbors from the area.  She attends to them with great kindness and warmth.  Elvia has been in the taxi rental business for more than three years and it has enabled her to earn more income to cover her household expenses.  

She has sole responsibility of taking care of her young son who is in school.   In addition, Elvia has another business in which she sells clothing from her home.  This business allows her to generate extra income. Her dream is to grow her business and equip it with other accessories that will permit her to work from the comfort of her home. She would like to invest in the purchase of clothes to offer to her clients and in this way earn more income.

loans.use: to purchase merchandise and to maintain her vehicles

loans.name: Petita

texts.es:
En el cantón 24 De Mayo de la  provincia de Manabí se reúne cada quince días el Banco Comunal Madre Para Un Futuro Mejor. Este cantón es conocido por sus paisajes hermosos, por sus bosques, por la variedad de su fauna y por su gente amable y  trabajadora que en su mayoría se dedica a la agricultura y ganadería.
 
En este lugar conocimos a la señora Petita, ella tiene 78 años de edad, está casada y de esta relación tuvo 13  hijos, cuatro de ellos fallecieron y los restantes ya son mayores de edad, dos de ellos  aun viven con ella. Su esposo es comerciante.

Se dedica a la venta de ropa, tiene un local en su casa en el que trabaja todos los días desde las 8h00  hasta las 18h00 con la ayuda de una de sus hijas. Su mercadería  se la envían desde New York o de Santo Domingo y ella la recibe en Portoviejo. Nos cuenta que lleva con su negocio ocho años y que gracias a Dios siempre le ha ido muy bien.

Este crédito es para comprar pantalones, camisetas, blusas, ropa de niños, interiores, entre otras prendas.  Ella está en el Banco Comunal 15 años y le gusta todo. Su sueño  tener un gran local.
texts.en:
The communal bank "Madre Para Un Futuro Mayor" (Mother for a Better Future) meets every 15 days in the canton 24 de Mayo in the Manabí province. This canton is known for its beautiful landscapes, for its forests, for the variety of its wildlife, and for its kind and hard-working people, of whom the majority work in agriculture and raising livestock.

In this place we met Señora Petita. She is 78 years old. She is married and from this relation has 13 children; four of them are deceased, and the others are adults. Two of them still live with her. Her husband is a businessman.

Señora Petita sells clothes. She has a shop in her house where she works every day from 8 am to 6 pm with the help of one of her daughters. Her merchandise is sent to her from New York or Santo Domingo and she receives it in Portovieho. She tells us that she has had her business for eight years, and thanks to God it has always gone well for her.

This loan is to buy pants, shirts, blouses, children's clothing, and underwear, among other items. She has been in the communal bank for 15 years and she likes it. Her dream is to have a big store.

loans.use: to buy pants, shirts, blouses, children's clothing, underwear, etc.

loans.name: Kribian Del Rosario

texts.es: Kribian del Rosario S. Velazquez es madre soltera y se dedica a la venta de salchipollo y hamburguesas en las afueras de su casa, eligió esta actividad hace 2 años por que tenia que mantener a su pequeña hija ya que no cuenta con el apoyo economico de su ex pareja, su meta a futuro es tener su propio restaurante donde quiere vender  todo tipo de aperitivos al paso y comidas tipicas de esta region, ella cuenta con  buenas referencias personales y es muy conocida y apreciada por sus vecinos ,con el dinero comprara mesas y sillas para su negocio y asi poder atender mejor a sus clientes
texts.en: Kribian del Rosario S. Velazquez is a single mother and sells salchipollo (a local dish made with chicken, french fries and seasonings) and hamburgers. She chose this activity because she needed to support her little daughter, since she could not count on help from her ex husband. Her goal for the future is to have her own restaurant with every type of fast food appetizers. She has good personal references. She is very well known and appreciated by her neighbors. She will buy tables and chairs for her her business and thus be able to attend to her clients.

loans.use: to purchase tables and chairs for her business

loans.name: Joefrey's Group

texts.en:
Joefrey A. is from the village of Mansabay Bajo, Lopez Jaena, Mis. Occ. He is 24 years old. Joefrey is the group leader of a two-member group loan offered by GDMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. Joefrey is married and has two school-age children. To make a living, Joefrey owns and operates a fishing business. The main source of income for the business comes from harvesting and selling ocean-caught fish in the local community. Joefrey has been engaged in his business for over four years and earns approximately 1,880 PHP a month for these activities. In 2011, Joefrey joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Joefrey A.'s group is requesting a loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional fishing nets and fish to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Joefrey from GDMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. About GDMPC:
GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has seven branches covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional fishing net and fish to sell

loans.name: Remedios

texts.en:
Remedios P. is from the village of Mansabay Bajo, Lopez Jaena, Mis. Occ. She is 58 years old. Remedios is married and has six adult children. To make a living, Remedios owns and operates a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling food products in the local community. Remedios is just starting this business. In 2008, Remedios joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Remedios has successfully repaid a previous loan from GDMPC. Remedios is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase canned goods, noodles, sugar, milk, and coffee to sell. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Remedios from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. About GDMPC:
GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has seven branches covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase canned goods, noodles, sugar, milk, and coffee to sell

loans.name: Antonia

texts.en:
Antonia is a 51-year-old widow who supports her family by operating a fishing/fish vending business. She lives in the island of Cebu. 

Antonia joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2000 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 19 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Antonia has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 15,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 7,000, uplifting the family's standard of living. 

This time, for her 20th loan, she is borrowing PHP 15,000 to buy a new fishing boat so that she can continue to save up for the future education of her children. Antonia is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

loans.use: to purchase a new fishing boat

loans.name: Sourn

texts.en:
Sourn T., age 66, is a widower who has four children. Three are single and two of them are working. One is married and lives independently. 

Sourn T. is highly skilled at building stone and wooden houses. He lives in Kompong Tom province. He has a few laborers to help provide his service. He receives a lot of orders from his clients to construct their houses. 

Recently, Sourn T. has been very busy at his business due to there being many clients who need him to build their houses, but he is still lacking material for construction. That is why Sourn T. requested a loan as capital to buy extra construction materials.

loans.use: to buy extra construction materials

loans.name: So

texts.en: The woman in the photo is So L., aged 65, who lives in the province of Kompong Tom in Cambodia. She earns a living by raising pigs. She has run this business for many years and it has provided her with income to attain her current standard of living. In addition, So L. also sells different kinds of dessert near her village in order to make additional income. So L. is married with four children; all of them are married, and two of them are employed in different jobs. Her husband is a firewood seller as well as a local farmer. So L. is asking for a loan to buy two cows to be used in her farming business.

loans.use: to buy two cows

loans.name: Esterlina

texts.en:
Esterlina L. is from the village of Mobod, Oroquieta City. She is 60 years old. Esterlina is widowed and has five adult children. To make a living, Esterlina owns and operates a service-based business. The main source of income for the business comes from providing transportation services in the local community. Esterlina has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month for these activities. In 2011, Esterlina joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Esterlina is requesting a new loan of 18,000 PHP, which will be used to renew transportation licenses. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Esterlina from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. About GDMPC:
GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has seven branches covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to renew transportation licenses

loans.name: Melba

texts.en: Melba is a 41-year-old widow who supports her family by operating a sari-sari store. She lives in Hinigaran, Negros Occidental. Melba joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2004 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 12 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Melba has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 20,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 10,000, uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her 13th loan, she is borrowing PHP 20,000, to purchase more stock to sell so that she can continue to save up for the future and for household consumption. Melba is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

loans.use: to purchase more stock to sell in her general store

loans.name: Myrna

texts.en:
Myrna U. is from the village of Villaflor, Oroq. City. She is 47 years old. Myrna is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Myrna owns & operates a business running a food stall selling snacks in the local community.  Myrna has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 1000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2011, Myrna joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Myrna is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP, which will be used to purchase ingredients and plastic wares. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Myrna from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has seven branches covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase ingredients and plastic wares

loans.name: Chem

texts.en: Chem S. is married and resides with her husband in Takeo province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-Angkorean temples. S. is a weaver, earning an income of USD 2.8 per day. Her husband is a motor-taxi driver, earning an income of USD 6 per day. Each month, the family has to spend USD 20 on food and USD 66 on the other necessary expenses. S. is requesting a loan of USD 1200 to purchase more raw silk to produce silk products. In the future, she would like to use the additional income to repair her house. This will be her second loan from CREDIT, a long standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: to buy more raw silk to produce silk products

loans.name: Estrellita

texts.en:
Estrellita B. is from the village of Lugdungan, Dipolog City. She is 61 years old. Estrellita is widow and has 3 adult children. To make a living, Estrellita owns & operates a business primarily planting rice.  She is also engaged in the pig raising business. Estrellita has been engaged in her business for over 7 years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2006, Estrellita joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Estrellita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase piglets and feeds. Estrellita is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizers for her rice field. This loan will be the 8th loan taken out by Estrellita from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About PMPC
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. 

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers for rice farming

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine is 40 years old and married with two children.

Josephine works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines. She requested a PHP 19,000 loan through NWTF to purchase more stock to sell in her general store.

Josephine has borrowed and paid six loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for four years and also earns an income from food vending.

Josephine aspires to renovate her house.

loans.use: To purchase more stock to sell in her general store

loans.name: Rocila

texts.en:
Rocila is 51 years old, married, and has 4 children. Her oldest child is 21 years old. All her four children go to school.

Rocila is a farmer. She plants and harvests rice crops. She sells her harvest to her community. Aside from rice farming, she also grows pigs that she sells to the market.

Rocila requested a loan of PHP 17000, which she will use to purchase fertilizes and pig feeds. Rocila hopes to have a stable business. She also wishes for her children to finish college and have bright futures.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and pig feeds

loans.name: Men

texts.en: Men K. is married and resides with her husband in Takeo province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-angkorean temples. K. sells brooms, earning an income of $4 per day. Her two children are employed at the factory, earning an income of $6 per day. Each month, the family has to spend $45 on food and $55 on the other necessary expenses. K. is requesting a loan of $1,000 to purchase a motorbike for her children to commute to work. In the future, she would like to use the additional income to repair her house. This will be K.'s first loan from CREDIT, a long standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for her children to commute to work

loans.name: Tuy

texts.en: Tuy K. has been in the fishing business for a long time. He and his wife always take their boat toward the middle of the river every morning, and then catch fish. When the fishing is done, they hurry to bring their fish to the market and sell to their regular buyers. Tuy K. and his wife also support their six single children, all of whom still live under their care. The family typically makes around $7 of profit each day to ensure that they have a comfortable standard of living. Tuy K. will use his loan to purchase nets and other fishing implements so he can catch more fish.

loans.use: to purchase nets and other fishing implements

loans.name: Mary Love

texts.en:
Mary Love P. is from the city of San Roque Ozamiz City. She is 26 years old,  single, and has one infant child. To make a living, Mary Love owns and operates a transportation services business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from operating motor transport services. Mary Love has been engaged in her business for over one year and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month.

In 2011, Mary Love joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Mary Love has successfully repaid a previous loan  from GDMPC. Mary Love is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP, which will be used to repair her existing vehicle for better service. This loan will be Mary Love's second loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has seven branches  covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherpeople, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To repair existing vehicle for better service

loans.name: Nourn

Nourn N. is married and resides with his wife in Takeo province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-Angkorian temples. Nourn is a construction worker earning an income of 4 USD per day. His wife sells brooms, earning 4 USD per day. Each month the family has to spend 60 USD on food and 70 USD on other necessary expenses.

Nourn is requesting a loan of 1,200 USD. This will be his first loan from CREDIT, a longstanding Kiva partner. He would like to purchase a motorbike for their children to commute to work. In the future, Nourn would like to use additional income to repair his house.

Ella joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2007 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past five loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Ella has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 10,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 7,000, uplifting the family's standard of living. 

This time, for her sixth loan, she is borrowing PHP 11,000 to purchase more raw materials so that she can continue to save up for future business and family needs. Ella is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

They have two single children, both of whom are employed in the garment industry. Mrs. But S. is requesting a loan to buy a new motorbike for her daughters to travel to work as they currently have to hire a taxi. With the remainder of the loan, But S. will buy housing materials for repairing her old house.

With the help of her past four loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Chineta has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. This time, for her fifth loan, she is borrowing PHP 15,000 to buy stock for the store and additional capital for buying and selling scrap so that she can continue to save up for the future education of her children. Chineta is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

Her previous loan of PHP 19,500, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Nora aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future wellbeing by following the Dungganon way.

Marites aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way.

loans.name: Marilyn's Group

texts.en:
Marilyn R. is from the village of Siempre Viva Norte. She is 42 years old and the group leader of a seven-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Marilyn R.'s Group.

Marilyn is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, she owns a general store selling a variety of different products. Marilyn has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 2,500 PHP a month. 

In 2007, Marilyn joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI and is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the ninth loan taken out by Marilyn from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children. 

About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.name: Boeun

texts.en:
Boeun T. is a 34-year-old farmer who lives in Phnom Penh City, Cambodia. She is married to Nuon SoT., aged 38. The couple, who work together in the farming business, has one child who is still studying in the local school. They generate an income of around $11 per day from their farming business, which they use to meet their family expenses. In this family, there is no additional income except from Boeun T. and her husband.
Boeun T. has applied to borrow $1,200 to buy two cows to serve their farming business. She will be able to make additional income after receiving this loan. The loan will make life easier than before because they will be able to use the cows’ labor in the rice field.

This time, for her fourth loan, she is borrowing PHP 15,000 to buy additional stock to sell so that she can continue to save up for her children's future education and house improvement. Alalay sa Kaunlaran, Inc., or ASKI, is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fishermen and -women, and small entrepreneurs.

texts.en: Vilma is a married woman who lives in Hinigaran, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating three business ventures: videoke, food vending and ready to wear clothing. Her husband David, who is 71 years old, works as a farmer to earn his living. They have six children who are between 19 and 42 years old. Vilma joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2008 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past six loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Vilma has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 15,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 4,000, uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her seventh loan, she is borrowing PHP 17,000 to purchase ingredients for her food vending business so that she can continue to save up for future family needs. Vilma is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

loans.use: to purchase ingredients for her food vending business

loans.name: Sem

texts.en:
Sem S., 50 years old, owns a small wooden kiosk where she sells soft drinks, sweets and cooking ingredients. She typically makes around US $1 in profit each day to use for the family. 

She was married to Mr. Bunthat, age 48, who is a rice farmer in the Kompong Cham province. She now has four children, two of whom attend high school. 

Sem S. also has one brother who still lives with her under her roof, and he is a recycling seller. Sem S. would like to ask for a loan for her brother to buy a second-hand motorbike for transportation of his used goods.

loans.use: to buy a secondhand motorbike for her brother to transport his used goods

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en: Gloria, 48 years old, lives in the town of Sto. Niño, South Cotabato with her family. She is married to a farmer and they have six children, the oldest 28 years old. Gloria, also a farmer, grows rice and corn, some for family consumption, with the rest sold to the market. She has requested a loan to purchase rice seeds, fertilizers and pig feed and hopes for her business to prosper.

loans.use: to purchase rice seeds, fertilizers and pig feed

loans.name: Bernabe

texts.en:
Bernabe C. is from the village of Pianon, Kalawit, Zamboanga del Norte. She is 46 years old. Bernabe is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Bernabe owns & operates a service-based business. The main source of income for the business comes from providing general services to local community members. Bernabe has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 8000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2011, Bernabe joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Bernabe is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Bernabe from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en: Cecilia is a married woman who lives in Victorias, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating a fishing/fish vending business. Her husband Francisco, who is 57 years old, works as a fisherman to earn his living. They have four children who are between 12 and 26 years old. Cecilia joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2003 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 10 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Cecilia has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 19,500 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 4,500, uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her 11th loan, she is borrowing PHP 22,000 to purchase a fishing boat so that she can continue to save up for the future, to improve business and for her children's education. Cecilia is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

loans.use: to purchase a fishing boat

loans.name: Nasreen's Group

texts.en:
Nasreen lives in Kamoki which is a small city of Punjab Pakistan and is famous for its agriculture industry. She has been living there in a 4 room brick house with her family in the area of Bilal park for past 25 years. 

She is a housewife, prefers to stay at home and does her household responsibilities. She is very caring person and takes care of her family very well. 
Her husband M. S. operates a spare parts shop through which he sells motorbike and auto vehicle spare parts and earns income for the family. 

Nasreen is the mother of 3 sons. All of them are involved in different works. Her eldest son works with his father’s spare parts shop. The 2nd son works in a factory for a low income and the youngest one is a private employee. 

She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for buying spare parts for the expansion of her husband’s spare parts business. She is hopeful that the loan support will enable him to increase his sales and earn larger profits. 

Nasreen is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her 4th loan application. She has proved herself as a responsible client by paying her installments on time in previous loan years. 

Note: In the photo, the lady holding the book (called Asasah Passbook) is Nasreen

loans.use: to buy spare parts for sale

loans.name: Jesusema

texts.en:
Jesusema is a 57-year-old married woman with 11 children. The oldest child is 38 years old. Her younger children still go to school.

Jesusema is a farmer. She tills land located in Sto. Niño, South Cotabato. She plants and harvests rice crops that she sells to the market.

Jesusema needs seed and fertilizers. She requested for a loan that she will use to fund her farm. Jesusema wishes for a stable business.

loans.use: to purchase seed and fertilizers

loans.name: Virginia

texts.en:
Virginia R. is from the village of Bandera, Polanco Zamboanga del Norte. She is 43 years old, married, and has 4 school-aged children.

Virginia owns and operates a specialized in agricultural sector in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 3,500 PHP a month.

In 2006, Virginia joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and improve her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell.

Virginia is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP which will be used to purchase feed and vitamins for her new hog-fattening business. This loan will be her 5th from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from her business to improve the general living conditions of her family.About PMPC
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. 

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase feed and vitamins for her pigs.

loans.name: Melisa

texts.en:
Melisa is a married woman who lives in Cebu. She earns her living by operating a business buying and selling pigs. Her husband Jesus, who is 48 years old, works as a farmer to earn his living and helps in his wife's business activities.  They have three children who are between 20 and 25 years old. 

Melisa joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2000 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 16 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Melisa has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 15,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 6,000, uplifting the family's standard of living.  

This time, for her 17th loan, she is borrowing PHP 18,000 to buy supplies for her pigs so that she can continue to save up for the future education of her children. Melisa is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

loans.use: to purchase supplies (feed, medicine) for her pigs

loans.name: Chhum

texts.en:
Chhum S. is a 62-year-old widowed mother caring for six children. All four of the children who are still living in the family home are employed in different jobs. 

She makes a profit by cultivating a rice crop on her own farmland, which came from her grandparents years ago. 

Chhum S. has a son who is a recycling seller. He buys used goods to sell to a wholesaler, who then sells the goods in bulk to other countries. The used goods he deals in are mostly leftover electricity wires. 

Chhum S. is looking for a loan for her son to buy a used motorcycle for picking his items up. This will enable him to purchase more used goods and increase his profit.

loans.use: to purchase a used motorcycle for her son's recycling business

loans.name: Jefrey

texts.en:
Jefrey M. is 23 years old and single. He is from the village of Quiling within Roxas municipality, a part of Isabela province on the Luzon islands. Jefrey sells agricultural materials and equipment such as crop fertilizers and manure to local farmers. Jefrey is just starting this business.

In 2011, Jefrey joined ASKI to gain access to its financial services. Jefrey is requesting a loan of 50,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand his product offering. This will be Jefrey’s first loan from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated to expand his business.

About ASKI:

Alalay sa Kaunlaran, Inc., or ASKI, is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fishermen and -women, and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Ket

texts.en: Ket C. lives with her family in Takeo province, Cambodia, an area known for its pre-Angkorean temples. C. is a weaver, earning an income of  $1.5 USD per day. Her husband is a electrician, earning an income of $4 USD per day. Each month, the family has to spend $75 USD on food and $50 USD on other necessary expenses. C. is requesting a loan of $600 USD to purchase equipment for her husband to improve his business. In the future, she would like to use the additional income to repair her house. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a longstanding Kiva partner.

loans.use: to buy electrical equipment for her husband's business

loans.name: Arlene Cenas Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Arlene C. is 52 years old, married and is a resident of Purok Makiangayon, Maningcol, Ozamiz City, Misamis Occidental. Arlene is the group leader of this two-member group loan offered by Kiva partner, PMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are both responsible for paying back the loan of their fellow group member if they are delinquent or default. The official name of this borrowing group is Arlene C.’s Group.
Arlene is married to Vidal C., a fisherman and farmer. They are blessed with five children, all married. To help her husband, Arlene decided to engage in fish vending and some farming activities together with her husband. For 40 years, she has been able to maintain the said business activity and now she is earning an average net income of not less than 3,000 PHP per month, which is so helpful to their family income.
Arlene joined the cooperative in 2007. As an active member of the PDP-LP (Paglaum Development Program for Landless People) program of PMPC, a microfinance program that reaches out to the rural poor, she is requesting an amount of 5,000 PHP as her sixth loan, which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital for her sari-sari store business.
The future income from this loan will be used to improve the living conditions of Arlene’s family, to meet their basic needs, for loan repayments to PMPC, and for possible business expansion. About group loans
In a group loan, each member of the group receives an individual loan but is part of a group of individuals bound by a group guarantee. Under this arrangement, each member of the group supports one another and is responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory and working capital for her sari-sari store

Cerilina has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately 13,000 PHP per month from these activities. 
Cerilina joined Kiva partner, PMPC, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from PMPC. This loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Cerilina is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This loan will be her fourth from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About PMPC
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

Lucila's loan will be used to purchase fertilizers and additional merchandise to sell in her store.

loans.name: Emelia Abadan's Group

While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are both responsible for paying back the loan of their fellow group member if they are delinquent or default. In 2010, Emelia joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is an active member of PMPC under the PDP-LP, a microfinance program that reaches out to rural communities. She joined the program because she is very much interested in the savings, insurance and other benefits offered by PMPC. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP. She is now requesting a loan of 4,000 PHP as her fourth loan, which will be used to purchase fertilizer for corn production.

loans.name: Oun

texts.en: Oun P. lives with her family in Takeo province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-Angkorean temples. She is a farmer, earning an income of 2 US dollars per day. Her husband sells soy milk, and earns 3 US dollars per day. Each month, the family has to spend 11 dollars on food and 30 dollars on other necessary expenses. P. is requesting a loan of USD 600 to purchase a motorbike for the children to commute to work. In the future, she would like to use any additional income to repair her house. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: to buy a motorbike for the children to commute to work

loans.name: Nazia's Group

texts.en:
Nazia is a seamstress by trade. She sews clothes for her neighboring clients in order to share the financial burden with her husband. She is very skillful and receives regular orders from her neighborhood clients every month. She completes their orders on time and has a good reputation for her good work in the community. 

She is also a very good housewife and does her household duties, staying at home.  She has given birth to a son and five daughters. She couldn’t enroll any of her children in school except her eldest daughter. Her husband operates a grocery store in the market. Through his store, he sells daily use items such as salt, sugar, cooking oil, spices etc. He is well known among his clients due to his good behavior and reasonable prices. 
 
Nazia has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband’s business. With the loan, her husband will buy groceries in bulk to put into his store to sell. This will allow him to offer more variety of products to his customers and earn better profits. Nazia is hopeful that an investment will make her husband’s business more profitable and will also expand his business. 

Note: In the photo, the lady with a book (called Asasah Passbook) is Nazia.

loans.use: To buy groceries for grocery store business.

loans.name: Zohra's Group

texts.en:
Zohra is a widow who lost her husband a few years ago. It was a very difficult time for her but she never lost hope. She raised her two sons with great care. They had to finish their education after matriculation and started working to financially contribute to the family. Both of them are involved in a cable-operating business. Through this service, people are able to watch different channels on television. 

Zohra is a resident of Kamoki. It is a small industrial city also known for its rice and other agricultural crops. She has been living in the area of Bilal Park with her family in a two-room brick house for the past many years. 

Zohra has applied for a loan from Kiva's partner, Asasah, to improve her sons' business because they have a large order to fulfill. With the loan, they will purchase cable in large quantity to meet the order on time. They have been doing this business for the past five years. Zohra wants to marry off her eldest son, who is now 29 years old, and she hopes that improvements in the business will help her save some money for that purpose. 

In the photo, the lady with a book (an Asasah passbook) is Zohra.

loans.use: to buy cables for a cable-operating business.

loans.name: Josefina

Josefina has been in her business for over five years and earns approximately 10,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month. In 2009, Josefina joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from HSPFI which was used to purchase additional inventory and for working capital. Josefina is requesting a new loan of 14,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional canned goods, detergents and snack foods. This will be her fourth loan from HSPFI. She plans to use additional income to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. loans.name: Jamin

texts.en:
Jamin is married with six children between the ages of 4 and 14 years; all attending school. He has been practicing mixed farming in his hometown of Kitale in Western Kenya for 20 years. His farm produces maize, beans and millet which are sold at the local market. His family entirely depends on farming for their upkeep.

Jamin has requested a loan of 52,000 Kenyan shillings from Juhudi Kilimo to enable him to purchase and insure a dairy cow. He says he will use the income to better provide his family with basic requirements like meals and education, besides having a long-term plan of expanding his farm through the purchase of more land to be able to practice zero grazing. Jamin notes that poor road networks and low prices for produce are the encumbrances in a farming business.

loans.use: to purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Munhbat

texts.en:
Munhbat, 54, is married and lives with his wife and four children in Uvurhangai province of Mongolia. They live in a house on a small plot of land that they've owned for seven years. His older son and daughter have their own jobs and his two younger daughters attend college in Ulaanbaatar, the capital of Mongolia. 

Munhbat began operating a retail trade in rawhides in 2004. He purchases animal rawhides from individuals and transports them by his own mini-truck. His wife sells meat at a rented stall at a local food market. There are a lot of competitors in this business and having a car is an advantage for their family-based business. They can go to the countryside and purchase meat, animal rawhides and livestock for cheaper prices from individuals and save money on transportation fees. Munhbat and his wife want to expand their meat trading business and increase their profit. Munhbat is a hardworking and active person who says, "I want to save some more money and help my son to build his own house in the future." He is requesting a loan of 2,500,000 tugriks to purchase more animal rawhides and meat for his business.

loans.use: to purchase more animal rawhides and meat.
